name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the question with a request for an oral reply to the Commission on the response to the reports on the treatment of insecurity and misuse of fixed-term contracts, submitted by Cecilia Wikström, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions (O-000054/2018 - B8-0022/2018) (2018/2600(RSP)

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: author. – Mr President, in the name of my committee – the Committee on Petitions – I am very proud to present the oral question and the resolution responding to petitions on tackling precariousness and the abusive use of fixed-term contracts. My committee has received, during the past few years, 80-plus petitions on the use of fixed-term contracts, zero-hours contracts and temporary contracts from different Member States (actually10 different Member States) and therefore the committee decided in November to organise a hearing under the title ‘Protection of the rights of workers in temporary or precarious employment’. The hearing looked in detail at all the issues raised in these petitions. A study on temporary contracts was also commissioned by Policy department C, and was presented during the hearing. It focused on two broad areas: first, atypical forms of employment and franchising; and, second, recommendations on adopting a holistic, comprehensive approach to address these problems. In January of this year, the committee coordinators unanimously decided, as a follow-up to these two activities, to draft an oral question and a motion for a resolution responding to petitions. In May this year, we also adopted the oral question and the amended draft for a motion. So the oral question tabled by the committee focuses on the correct implementation of EU law regarding the protection of workers in the EU, and on the compatibility of some specific types of contract, such as the currently much-talked-of zero-hours contracts, with European legislation – i.e. whether there is compatibility or not. Thirdly, action is needed to address the abusive use of fixed-term contracts and precarious forms of employment. We want to ensure proper implementation of employment directives in the public and private sectors. We have also highlighted the legislation proposed by the Commission and the need to ensure the predictability and sustainability of employment. And, lastly, we want to ask the Commission about the state of play in current infringement procedures for violation of EU labour legislation. When you look at the text of the resolution, you should bear in mind the increase in the number of workers with fixed-term and part-time contracts and the significant increase in temporary employment contracts and atypical contracts, in both the public and private sectors. In the light of this large number of petitions that we have received, we consider there is a need for a debate on the situation of workers in the European Union. We would have liked to do this together with the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, but it takes two to tango and we were simply turned down. Nevertheless, we, as the Petitions Committee, need to address all those citizens everywhere in the Member States who actually came to us pointing out their difficulties. We must not forget that petitions are a reflection of citizens and their situation, and are an important signalling mechanism to the legislative committees of this House and to the Commission. These petitions reveal gaps in the legislation, or in the implementation of legislation, and the petitions sent to my committee regarding precarious employment should therefore be taken extremely seriously. We would like – and I am talking here on behalf of all the political groups in the Committee – to invite the Commission not only to review the legal instrument but also to think of how, in future, to avoid the harmful situations of which all these people are victims. We should find ways to ease the life of EU citizens who are suffering from precariousness, and the oral question and the resolution have been put on the plenary agenda in order to draw attention to the concrete problems faced by European citizens. We are – and I personally am – now expecting the Commission not only to reply to the specific points in the oral question but also to commit to making all the necessary efforts to ensure the best possible protection of all workers in the European Union. They deserve it.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, addressing precarious work remains high on the Commission’s agenda. I referred to the debate which took place in July 2017 when Parliament adopted its resolution on working conditions and precarious employment. The Commission has provided comprehensive answers to your resolution and has also proposed new initiatives. Our priority now is to ensure that the prosperity generated by the recovering European economy benefits society fairly. We made huge efforts and the economy is growing again. But we are not done yet; we must ensure that no one is left behind. This is the essence of the European Pillar of Social Rights, jointly proclaimed in November last year. Today’s debate is essentially about our ability to bring the Pillar agenda forward together – in the Commission, Parliament and the Council. On the Commission side, in recent years we have set milestones in the social area. Before the end of this mandate, we must show EU citizens, in a very tangible way, our determination to make the Union fairer and more inclusive. We should not ignore the fact that precarious work has a toll, not only on individuals but on our societies and economies as a whole. The Union has developed and extended its response to this issue over the years. It has done so through specific EU directives on non-standard forms of work and through enhanced cooperation and coordination with the Member States. This cooperation includes the European Platform on Undeclared Work. This year we issued country-specific recommendations in the European Semester on tackling the informal and shadow economy for Bulgaria and Italy. The European Social Fund provides financial support for disadvantaged youth or the long-term unemployed. Let me assure you that the Commission is strongly committed to ensuring compliance across the EU. Where necessary, we initiate infringement proceedings, which may ultimately lead the Commission to refer the matter to the Court. The work undertaken by the Committee on Petitions strongly supports and influences our efforts to ensure effective action is undertaken. Thank you so much for this support. We took concrete actions and put forward a comprehensive set of proposals: firstly, for a directive on predictable and transparent working conditions; secondly, for a Council Recommendation on access to social protection for workers and the self-employed; and thirdly, for a regulation establishing a European labour authority. Through these initiatives, we want to prevent EU workers from being subjected to unfair and precarious working conditions by guaranteeing basic standards for all workers, including workers subject to particularly flexible forms of employment, such as on-demand work or zero-hour contracts; by ensuring social protection coverage regardless of the employment status; and by supporting administrative cooperation and better information to enforce existing rules. All workers in non-standard forms of employment must benefit from these basic standards. Current EU rules often leave their scope to be determined by national law, which has left out too many workers from protection. It is essential for our initiatives on working conditions that all workers are covered. This legislative work must be pursued with utmost celerity so that we make these further steps towards fairness and inclusiveness in employment together before the elections.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by underlining the importance of petitions. This is the way that citizens communicate with us directly and inform us about breaches of EU law. For us, the EPP Group, precarious employment means employment that does not respect European and national law. We want to guarantee flexibility for employers but, at the same time, proper social security for all types of workers. Now, I need to point out a few facts about this resolution. First of all, I would like to remind you that the conversion of a fixed-term contract into an indefinite one is not an obligation for Member States, but an exclusive national competence. We should not mix EU and national competences regarding labour and social policies. Secondly, when we speak about different directives, we have to recall the fact that they are in place especially to prevent abuses. Thirdly, when we refer to specific cases, we have to take into account all the observations of the Court of Justice of the European Union. In addition to the current legislation, the Commission issued in December a proposal for a directive on transparent and predictable working conditions in the EU and adopted proposals for a European labour authority and for better access to social protection. I welcome these proposals aimed at improving the existing legislation.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in my home region of the North East of England, unemployment reached an all-time low this year, falling below 5%, a figure that would appeal to many economy ministers across Europe. But there’s a catch, because, in the North East, we are the capital for zero-hours contracts in the UK. One out of ten workers has a precarious job, most of them in the form of a zero-hours contract. Not only does a zero-hours contract come with job insecurity but precariousness at work also leads to inadequate access to social protection, such as benefits and protection from unfair dismissal. It impinges on career development and training and therefore results in precariousness in life more generally. We, as the Committee on Petitions in this Parliament, have received a large number of petitions calling for European action. In 2016, the Committee on Petitions received submissions from McDonald’s workers who testified that some of their most basic rights, such as the right to maternity leave, paid holidays and redundancy rights, were being withheld because of zero-hours contracts. We have taken this up in Parliament, and I’m proud to support McDonald’s workers – including those brave people who have taken industrial action in the struggle for their rights at work – as well as all the other precarious workers across Europe with the resolution that we’re putting on the table today. We now need the Commission to act. Commissioner, your representatives confirmed in our Committee on Petitions’ hearing that zero-hours contracts fall within the remit of the EU Part-Time Workers’ Directive, which guarantees the same employment protection for part-time workers as for full-time workers. What will you now do to enforce these rules and give McDonald’s workers across Europe all of the rights that they deserve at work?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, austerity and violent fiscal adjustment have filled Europe with armies and millions of poor and unemployed. At the same time, they have led to lower wages and the breakdown of industrial relations. The famous objectives of post-war Europe for full employment have now become objectives and implementation in the field of part-time work, informal forms of work, precarious work, fixed-term work, zero-hours contracts. So we have a complete abuse of both Directive 1999/70/EC on fixed-term contracts and, overall, labour law in Europe. There is now a working jungle in Greece, as the troika and the memorial governments have broken up industrial relations and abolished collective labour agreements. We welcome yesterday's magnificent strike in Greece and the mobilizations of workers who sent a decisive message to the SYRIZA-ANEL government that it is no longer going to the issue of industrial relations. The armies of contract workers in Greece and the problem with the thousands of workers in stage programs demonstrate the huge problem that exists. In particular, Commissioner, the issue of the thousands of workers in stage programmes who have now been left out of work is a classic case of a breach of Community law. We call on you from this step to take concrete measures and to refer Greece, because it has violated European Union law and thus to vindicate the thousands of employees or former employees of the stage programmes. We in the Committee on Petitions, as the ECR Group and myself as coordinator, supported this initiative to question and discuss the case which concerns us. We must not allow the operation of fixed-term contracts to be abused. Not in the working jungle.

name: Yana TOOM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, petitions are an important signal for this Parliament. They show the concerns of Europeans and reflect the situation on the ground. In this case they showed problems regarding precarious work.  During this mandate the Committee on Petitions has received over 80 petitions from 10 different Member States on precariousness and abusive use of fixed-term contracts. As a response, the Committee organised hearings on these issues and now we have an oral question and a resolution.  This resolution sends a powerful message. It sends a message to the petitioners that we have heard them. It sends a message to those who are in precarious employment that we care, and it sends a message to the Commission and Member States that we all need to act.  In the last few years the labour market has been changing. There is a trend to move away from traditional contracts and to move towards more flexibility – flexibility for the employer and the employee. But this shift was not foreseen in the current EU labour laws. Therefore, it sometimes happens that these more flexible workers are less protected. As the labour market changes, we need to adapt.  The gaps in current laws should be closed to guarantee inclusive labour standards. But it is not only the EU which needs to act. The Member States have the most important task: they need to implement the laws to protect the workers. Incorrect implementation leads to insecurity. Infringement proceedings started by the Commission take a long time, even years, and during that entire period the workers suffer.  There are also occasions when Member States can do more, by introducing, for example, better safeguards against abusive use of fixed-term contracts. Member States have the competence and power and should definitely use it. I am therefore happy to see that this resolution covers these issues.  People in precarious working conditions are always in the weaker position. They need us to stand up for them and ensure that they are protected.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we are very concerned in our Committee on Petitions about the precariousness at work, as the President has just said. This question is the answer to many petitions on precariousness and abuse in employment contracts. The profile of the worker has changed in Europe. There's a new category of workers. Having a job is not having a life. Having a job now often means being poor. You've got work, you're poor. This is our reality. Europe's greatest job insecurity is in Spain, the state where precarious contracts are most worked, not by will, because it is already impossible to have an indefinite contract. 91.4% of the jobs in Spain are precarious. The origin is in the structure of the labor market. The possibility implies that having a job is in poverty. In Galicia, my country, one in four employees has a fixed-term contract, a precarious and temporary contract, with one of the highest rates in the European Union of 26.8 %. For youth, 3 out of 4 young people, or 73.3 %, have a temporary contract, followed by Slovenia, Poland, Portugal, Italy and Croatia. In addition, Spain also leads in precariousness.  This is a social risk for Europe, a social risk, Commissioner. That's why the 19th in Galicia, we're going on strike. That is also why we must make a motion of censure of precariousness at work.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, there are few of us in the Chamber this morning, but a few metres outside these walls, a few kilometres away from us, hundreds of thousands of people are a sad army of people living under the traumatic experiences of precarious work, not to mention unemployment. Hundreds of thousands of people suffer having a two-hour job a day because they supposedly can't be offered more, or four or six hours, and are paid perhaps much less than that. Hundreds of thousands of people, not to mention millions in the countries of the South, but also in the countries of Northern Europe, are living this incredible trauma of living under conditions that are not allowed in the modern European Union. Yesterday we were discussing here the possibility of company factories moving from state to state. Their right to carry their company wherever they want, as well as their tools, their cars, their buildings. People aren't tools to get them to move from one state to another. The two to which I refer are linked, and precarious work and the obligation to move around using the terrible argument of the right of free movement. That's a right, it's not an obligation. I conclude by saying that the issue we are discussing today concerns many of our brothers, our relatives, people outside this Chamber, but it is we who have to represent them.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, precarious employment is a scourge that exposes those who are victims of it to enormous socio-economic vulnerability. This is what this resolution says, which takes shape and substance from the many petitions sent by precarious workers, precarious workers in schools, health, public administration in general, but also in the private sector. It is clear that precarious jobs in the European Union have increased exponentially, and that this number has been aggravated by the obvious impact of austerity policies. It is also clear that there is a direct link between precarious working conditions and the absence of effective legislative measures to prevent and penalise discrimination and abuse of fixed-term contracts, as in the case of Italy. The European Commission has a direct responsibility for this because it has wasted time, accumulated delays and has therefore actuallyed the repeated and abusive use of fixed-term contracts in violation of workers' rights. For years, in fact, the European Court of Justice has ruled that EU legislation provides that permanent employment contracts must be the common form of employment relationships, and that fixed-term contracts are attributable only to the specific characteristics of certain sectors and to certain occupations and activities. Colleagues and Commissioner, in Italy we have even reached the limit case where a worker who has seen a favourable judgment by the labour court, who recognises him as a victim of the abusive and repeated use of fixed-term contracts, is dismissed. This is, of course, unacceptable, and we must put stability, dignity and effective social protection measures back at the centre of our work.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the fight against precariousness and the misuse of fixed-term contracts is becoming one of the many sea snakes in this Parliament and yet another resolution will do nothing about it. This is the impossible challenge of social convergence, such as this much-talked-about tax harmonisation. Finally, we believe that we are talking about it and hope that this will never happen, as social dumping is one of the engines of the economies of both The East and the West, but for divergent interests. Let us remember the obvious here. The precariousness of jobs will cease when and only when our respective economies have regained real growth that will mechanically generate employment. It is essential to protect ourselves from globalization through intelligent protectionism, accompanied by economic patriotism. In the Union, we have to buy what the Union produces, first of all.  In addition, there is an urgent need to combat social dumping organised by our own directives. Unfortunately, the revision of the detached workers directive, voted on Tuesday, shows that we are a long way off. Far from these objectives, which should be a priority, your draft resolution becomes a catch-all, where we find the now inevitable notions of inclusive work, gender equality, atypical and non-standard jobs, and the worst...  Let us also talk about the many contradictions of this proposal. You want to find solutions at European level when, in your recital B, you state, and I quote: 'EU social and labour policy is based on the principle of subsidiarity'. In Article 3, you want to promote safe and well-paying quality jobs and strengthen labour inspections, whereas in Article 6 you defend the right to seek additional employment, which is precisely precarious employment. What is really serious is the return of the vulnerability of the working poor, who can no longer afford housing, forced part-time cashiers, mini-contracts in endlessly renewed public services, zero-hours contracts with uncertain or even non-existent social protection. Worse, you are talking about the 1999/70/EC directive and you are hoping for action from the Commission, but the Commission itself is violating this text, with the temporary contracts of some of its agents, when they are permanent posts. Obviously, you still have a long way to go.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, when the capital's demand for flexible and temporary employment is the soul of European Union policy, it is a myth to protect precarious workers, such as the directive which, in the name of avoiding abuse, fixed-term contracts are not renewed and contract workers are dismissed. The directive does not promise permanent work. It's a myth. On the contrary, it threatens and punishes with an alleged obligation to permanentise anyone who does not regularly recycle more unemployed people. The vast majority of new hires are temporary. SYRIZA as an opposition considered this directive a permanent paradise. As a government, he's using it by laying off thousands of contract workers in the municipalities. In answer to questions from the JRC, the Commission makes it clear: the Directive does not provide for the conversion of fixed-term contracts into indefinite contracts. The European Union does not recognise a right to permanent and stable work. Indeed, the resolution itself speaks of not burdening employers, whose role is being upgraded, and maintaining the adaptability of the labour market. So finally, the myths. All-labor struggle for permanent work with rights, and the abolition of all forms of flexible employment.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I think it’s important as well, as others have said this morning, to recognise that when we have petitions from citizens, we need to pay attention and approach them with the correct attitude and in the spirit that they were meant. Actually, working conditions are a combination of EU and national competences, and I think we should recognise that and that there are differences, but I also think the European Union can play a very strong role in this area – and has done. The transparent and predictable working conditions currently in Parliament ... We’ve had a hearing recently in the Employment Committee and the European Labour Authority recognises that workers across Europe need to be protected. In my own country, in Ireland, we recently introduced legislation to ban zero—hours contracts and to address insecure contracts and for those who are working variable hours in precarious situations. All of that is there to prevent the exploitation of workers.  I’d say to employers that it is in their interest to ensure that their workers are committed to their job and to their employment and that, in turn, will create loyalty. We know well that if you exploit workers, you will not get committed workers in that area. But I’d also say to all of us who are consumers as well, and I know a colleague here earlier in the chamber mentioned a particular fast food chain, we have a voice to speak with if we are not content with the way those workers have been treated with regard to the unpredictability of their hours. The fast food chains can certainly predict their hours. They know their hours of opening, so they can certainly give more certainty in that area. I think as consumers we should use our voices as well because the world of work is changing, but at the same time, as consumers we will race to the bottom of the lowest price, but yet we want the best of standards, and we’re willing to buy online and neglect local retailers. I think we all have to play a role in this, but the most important thing is that we do recognise that workers are being exploited and can be exploited, and we need to work together to ensure that adequate protection is put in place to prevent precarious work, particularly zero—hours contracts, which are really giving our workers across the EU no certainty in terms of social commitments or commitments to their families.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Mr President, there are literally millions of workers in the United Kingdom on zero hours and other exploitative contracts, and the highest proportion of them is in my constituency in the West Midlands, which is the capital of zero-hours contracts in the United Kingdom. It will seem surprising to some here that a very large number of those people being exploited on those contracts in the United Kingdom – maybe even most of them, but certainly a very large number of those millions – will have voted for Brexit, and it is therefore the right answer that has been sent out from these institutions since the referendum that here, these institutions will deepen and re-double the efforts to tackle those abuses. That is the right answer to send to those people. However, in order for it to be a real answer, it has to be meaningful legislation, and this petition reflects the voice of our citizens. I did an INI report on this, which was great, but we have to say to the Commission that INI reports and petitions are no longer enough; we need real legislation, we need a recognition of this in the Written Statement Directive. The time for action has come.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to speak here as employment coordinator for ALDE and as rapporteur of the report on the Directive on the foresight and transparency of employment contracts. We are not talking about the 'zero hours' problem here: this will have to be dealt with by the EMPL Commission in the moment. We are talking about answering a number of citizens who have expressed concern about their employment situation and work situations, which in times of crisis is absolutely normal and, in fact, I am surprised that there are so few requests. There should be more, because we are all unhappy in a crisis situation. What I mean is that there are two kinds of questions. Those who say that the law has not developed in their country, etc.: that they go to the judges. And everyone who asks us to do things better. And of course, I would like to tell you that Parliament is at it, and that precisely the Directive on the foresight and transparency of employment contracts and the way of working, together with the work-life balance sheet, together with the number of social security, is a long-running, an offensive by Parliament, together with the Commission, to respond to these requests and improve labour markets for workers.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – I come from Slovenia, where there is a degree of precarity among the higher ones in Europe. Unfortunately, the cursing work represents and becomes a new form of 21st-century slave ownership. And precarity is, unfortunately, the only choice for many and is also anonymous with the harsh insecurity and condition where labour and social rights do not really exist. And this flexibility, the complete flexibility required of the worker, means that he must give up virtually everything, including his own dignity, to do so. Unfortunately, this is our practice. However, we must not forget, not at European level, not in the Member States, that the right to work is a fundamental human right, which means that it is a right of the highest legal rank, which, of course, also is guaranteed by international law, including the Constitution, and that this is not about justice, to any part, but to the right to decent work. And I think we owe it to future generations, too, to offer a future worthy of man.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Mr President, every time I am in Greece I face the despair of workers in conditions of safety. Women over 50 years old with temporary project contracts over 15 years. Unpaid teachers on nine-month contracts. Others on contracts of only 2 days a week. We also have employees who are hired in the morning and fired in the afternoon. That's what's happening elsewhere. In countries that didn't have memoranda, we know that. But the resistance is over. There has to be a convincing answer. The Eurobarometer tells us that 75% of citizens are not happy with the prospects in Europe. People can't wait any longer. You'll meet it in front of you if you don't change policy. So I ask you, what are the institutions of the European Union doing in practice for unprotected workers?

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our citizens today are paying, and evidently at great cost, for the last ten years of structural reforms that Europe has asked of us, and which have only led to an increase in precariousness, inequalities and poverty. In Italy, two and a half million workers have a fixed-term contract. Over the past three years, precarious employment has grown by 8.5 % as a result of the damage caused by the Jobs Act and good schools. In the last year alone, one million employment contracts have been created, but only 27 000 are for an indefinite period. The rest belongs to the jungle of non-standard contracts, such as zero-hours contracts, which have even increased by 124.7 %. These new forms of employment are also making the boundaries between employee and self-employment less clear, leading to a deterioration in the quality of work and an increase in fictitious self-employment. Today we have rulings certifying that there are no effective safeguards for those who are victims of abuse of fixed-term bargaining, in violation of European legislation on fixed-term work. Today, in essence, we certify the failure of the reforms implemented in our country, at Europe's request, because, as we always remember, imposing structural reforms without ex ante evaluation is truly detrimental.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to underline the importance of this petition, because the European Parliament should respond to the number of such petitions and violations of the Fixed-Term Employment Directive in the public sector, as well as to the precarious working conditions of workers with zero-hours contracts and the problems of representing trade unions and differences in social security systems. I would like to say that, for example, the Czech Republic changed its labour legislation just after joining the European Union or under the influence of joining the European Union, and that the impact of European law on the labour market was unequivocally positive. I would like to stress that I agree that states and, of course, european institutions should combat precarious employment, such as zero-hours contracts, by ensuring that European legislation is respected, and, in particular, the case law of the Court of Justice, as my colleagues have already pointed out. At the same time, I think that the European Commission should consider legislation that would effectively address the problem of employers' practices leading to precarious working conditions. On the other hand, I would like to stress that, even for employers, the conditions on the free competition market are also quite uncertain, and I therefore believe that one repeated fixed-term employment relationship is permissible. I agree, however, that worker certainty should also be strengthened. At the same time, I would like to conclude by condemning the extension of fixed-term employment contracts in order to cover needs that are not temporary in nature, that is, circumvention of legislation, where the employer abuses the possibility of re-entering into such employment.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: – Mr President, today, of course, we are bringing to debate and vote this motion for a Resolution of this Parliament condemning job precariousness in a context in which part-time and part-time contracts have multiplied across the Union over the past fifteen years.  In our group's view, we have entered a career in lower working conditions for workers throughout Europe and in my country, Spain, certainly exponentially.  The economic and financial crisis has been the perfect storm for investment markets, debt rating agencies, the European Central Bank and the neoliberal right in general to attack working-class living conditions.  We are, Commissioner, at a critical point, returning to levels of precarisation of work that have not been seen in Europe since the end of World War II. The scenario is terrible and the answer must therefore be, above all, also ideological.  Directives governing recruitment, labour protection in State legislation and social dialogue should be strengthened as a framework for regulating working conditions. There can be no social justice if we move towards new forms of covert slavery.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – (20) Mr President, the response to citizens who are being addressed massively by petitions to the European Union requires the utmost respect, which must be expressed in the quality of the response, which must be swift and cannot be evasive or out of date from regional, national and Community political and administrative realities.  We are dealing with citizens who trust the European Union and we are aware of the expectation that we will solve their problems, even against installed powers.  Commissioner, it is very serious that we receive numerous petitions from European citizens on situations of precariousness and misuse of fixed-term employment contracts, in violation of a European directive, which is the case both in the private sector and in the public sector. The numbers are scary. In Portugal, 82% of temporary workers are unintentionally affected by young people, which, according to a Commission assessment, shows a high labour segregation that needs to be corrected. These are situations in which, contrary to their expectations, workers are forced to accept part-time, seasonal work, with an indefinite or false independent work.  As regards the abuse of successive fixed-term contracts, the governments of the Member States themselves are the first to violate the European Directive, when they should be the first to set an example for the business sector. This is also the case in my country and in my region, especially in the teaching class. Meanwhile, the Commission ignores the heashes of complaints and arranges bureaucratic subterfuge to postpone or avoid responses that go against national governments. There is a duplicity of criteria that is unacceptable. If, on the one hand, we are demanding mechanisms to protect workers from the private sector – and very well –, we cannot, on the other hand, turn a blind eye to the action of national governments. Commissioner, it is necessary to give swift, adequate and unafraid answers to the powers in power, advocating a genuine Social Europe.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, what we are debating here today are the consequences of the treatment of the crisis, a treatment that opted for austerity to improve competitiveness and that what it brought us is a reduction in social rights, a reduction in wages, a reduction in labour standards — after all — of workers, insecurity and precarious work , which particularly affect women and young people, and which will drag the future of the European Union.  That is what we are debating today, the result of this treatment of the crisis.  But it is striking that there is broad European regulation and it is striking that, while this is happening, the European Union is looking the other way. And look the other way when petitioners even complain that their requests are not answered in time or they are not answered. And it's true.  Reforms have been demanded from here, measures have been required, but it has not been required that, at the same time, what the Labour Directive would require be guaranteed.  That is therefore what I ask the Commission to require such monitoring, compliance and to open the infringement files to be opened, and for those who are open to be concluded; but especially that the policies of the European Semester require compliance with labour standards.  I also ask you, in a very specific way, to take steps to eliminate and end, once and for all, the successive chaining of temporary contracts which are actually indefinite — this is happening throughout the European Union and must be terminated — and that zero-hour contracts be regulated. The European Commission therefore has a very important role to play in guaranteeing workers' rights and ending this burden which is the precarious work of European citizens.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, Council Directive 1999/70/EC states that indefinite contracts should be the general form of employment relationship. However, we live in the boom in atypical, temporary and part-time unwanted employment. There are States that systematically fail to comply with this legislation, but the Commission continues to delay the processing of infringement proceedings, just as it still does not respond to the increase in new requests on the matter. There are many groups affected by the precariousness trap: trainees, false freelancers, delivery men from Amazon and Deliveroo, the kellys , the hotel floor waitresses – the professional caregivers – mostly immigrant women – or, for example, the domestic workers, whom, in Spain, far from improving their conditions, an amendment by the People's Party and Citizens will delay them by five more years their incorporation into the General Social Security Regime, prolonging, unsustainably, their precariousness. The Commission must take steps to put an end to unfair terms and to opt for guarantee legislation, and we also need to take a time rearrangement seriously to think about the relationship between work and life that puts care and people at the centre.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – Mr President, no guarantee that you will be ready to pay your rent tomorrow. No guarantee either if you can work tomorrow and uncertainty about insurance for bad luck during work. No one wants uncertainty and yet there are employers – in my country, the Netherlands, first – who are increasingly addicted to flexible work.  On the one hand, we see the mountain of money from multinationals like McDonald's and Uber and those of their shareholders growing, and on the other hand they are not paying into the collective provisions and saddle their staff with precarious contracts. This makes the Deliveroos of this world the Dagobert Ducks of Europe. Work no longer seems to be a guarantee of not being poor, and therefore the economic cake must be distributed differently and more fairly. Increase the tax on capital, raise wages, as the IMF also advocates, and finally end the precarious contracts, because a job with uncertainty, that eats away at people.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to make a few additional comments in addition to my co-ordinator colleague, Mr Wasa. Firstly, precarious employment is an issue – of course, I could say that otherwise we would not have the petitions in the Committee on Petitions that are before us. Secondly, is there a need for action? Yes, there is a need for action! So where is the real problem? The real problem is that we have to be careful that we do not want too much in the end. It is basically a question of resolving the apparent conflict between fair and freedom of contract, and I think we can resolve this conflict, because for me there is always a line between decent and indecent.  It is precisely this border that we must formulate from a European point of view, and that is why I would also like to ask colleagues that we should concentrate on this important task. Sometimes we want too much, and we do not make the European Union any better if we adopt things here that are really not feasible in the Member States. That is why we are working together to resolve these precarious, indecent working conditions, to bring some order to the system and, of course, not to kill the freedom of contract.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, I fully support the initiatives of the Committee on Petitions. Capital and markets have globalized over the last thirty years, very strongly. Unfortunately, at the same time, labour rights for which the European Welfare State was known on a global scale were also not globally globalised.  The negative consequences of globalization have led to the emergence of the preariate, which is on track to replace the proletariat, even in some developed parts of the world. Young people, women and older workers have contributed greatly to redefining employment. The data shows that each generation is less represented in permanent employment than the previous one. Work and forced migration, as well as demographic changes, should be included in the analysis. For example, my homeland, the Republic of Croatia, is one of the countries with the highest percentage of the population over 60 years of age, and as many as 25% of workers work in precarious conditions.  This is a time of debate on the future of the European Union. They must offer answers to this serious problem, as over time European integration has proven to be one-sided. There was too much insistence on the market and monetary integration, and social and employment policies were largely ignored.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the field of work is one of those to which the European Union has failed. Instead of protecting workers' rights, he's trying to limit them. A few years ago, issues such as job security, misuse of fixed-term contracts, zero-hours contracts were unknown. Now, not only are they known, but they are also the basis of the functioning of the working system having created a working age in which European workers suffer, suffer and are humiliated, especially young people, especially the young people of Greece. All this is done to reduce wages and pensions and to oblige European workers to accept the demands of an anti-labour and unpopular labour system. This, after all, is why young people from third countries are allowed access to Europe and thousands of new illegal immigrants are being legalised. All of these are putting pressure on European young people to either accept the situation that exists or to remain unknown. I would like to believe that in the next European elections the brains of this unacceptable situation will receive the appropriate response.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, Commissioner, violations of the working conditions of a decent position predated the economic crisis. However, the balance between employers and workers has been for the worse since the financial crisis or with the threat of the economic crisis. To return to a level of balance that existed before collective agreements, this will take time. So the question we all face is how we limit employers' abusive attitudes towards employees. I think two are the tools. Either by new legislation or above all by effective implementation of existing and new legislation and I propose two things. One has been said by Mr Juncker: a new principle of implementation of legislation at pan-European level, including judicial decisions. The second: fast out-of-court mechanisms. Here Cyprus can set a good example. For example, I mean by avoiding abusive working conditions.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the broad support that the petitions have received sends a strong message about the need for immediate change. The abuse of rights by MacDonald's or other companies in the public or private sector must end immediately. Workers in precarious employment are even more vulnerable to socio-economic vulnerability and are more likely to lack the resources to lead a decent life. As the resolution stresses, "policies to combat precariousness must be adjusted to the dynamic nature of the resolution, all through integrated and integrated packages of measures that support inclusive and concrete labour standards, coupled with effective measures to ensure compliance with the principle of equality".  Furthermore, I share the view that the Commission and the Member States must tackle precarious employment, such as zero-hours contracts, by relying on new instruments and ensuring consistent compliance with the jurisprudence of the European Court of Justice, as well as the practical application of national and European legislation at national level, in order to combat the shortage of decent jobs and to implement a rights-based strategy.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate shows once more the relevance and the urgency of our initiatives to tackle precarious work. The Commission has tabled some proposals that specifically target precariousness in employment. No doubt new challenges are developing continuously in today’s labour market. There is a growing risk of lack of protection of workers, especially those in new and non-standard forms of employment. This is the situation on the ground. Therefore, our efforts must be sustained and intensified. As the Commission, we count on your support to rapidly translate the Commission’s recent proposals into reality, and with the degree of ambition and protection that EU citizens expect from the EU. We have to meet the expectations of our citizens.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I have received, in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure, a motion for a resolution. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 31 May.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on five motions for resolutions on the situation of prisoners with dual citizenship (EU-Iran) in Iran (2018/2717(RSP)

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. –Mr President, Iran’s detention of a number of dual nationals continues to place a strain on relations between it and EU Member States. Today’s resolution topic is sometimes lost in the midst of broader issues such as the unrelated JCPOA on the nuclear deal. Iran, sadly, continues to support terrorist groups and does indeed practice internal repression and human rights abuses at home. Many of these EU dual nationals, including Mrs Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a British citizen, have been detained on spurious charges without any recognised due process by international standards and are often denied access to consular assistance, as Iran doesn’t recognise their second EU nationality. Whilst detained, many are reported to face solitary confinement and cruel treatment during interrogation. So I today support the call for the release of all those detained solely for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly, but also for those, such as Zaghari-Ratcliffe, who are being detained on spurious charges invoking bogus national security concerns.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Our relationship with Iran is under particular strain as a result of the US's termination of the nuclear deal. We must do everything we can to ensure that this treaty remains in place so that it prevents nuclear armament throughout the region. However, this cannot in any way mean abandoning our principles. Of course, human rights are particularly important to us.  Today we will adopt a resolution asking Iran to review or overturn the sentences against people who have dual nationality – those of the EU and that of Iran. This must also be possible in this difficult situation. Especially among friends you can express wishes and requests. Anything else would be a sign of a lack of confidence.  Our Iranian partners know that we have completely different, opposite views in some areas – and especially in the case law. We have won our views in centuries of struggles. We cannot move away from this. I would therefore ask the Iranian authorities to let the four people mentioned in the resolutions return to Europe. This is particularly true of Dr Ahmadreza Djalali.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, I demand the release of unfairly-jailed persons and jailed human rights defenders, and that the EU must remain determined to put human rights concerns with Iran as a priority on every possible occasion. The arrests of dual nationals are part of a wider crackdown on human rights in Iran. Also, women are facing prosecution for protesting against Iran’s compulsory dress code. I am very worried about the reports of recent deaths in detention, especially as no Iranian official has ever been held accountable for the violations of human rights of persons in state custody. Cases where imprisoned individuals are sentenced to death are also extremely worrying. The EU is committed to the universal abolition and an immediate stop of the death penalty, and I am committed to seeing the stop of all state killings.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Since April 2016, Swedish-Iranian researcher Ahmadreza Djalali has been imprisoned in Iran. Amnesty International and independent UN experts consider the accusations against him to be baseless. Nevertheless, he is sentenced to death. This is an abuse of an individual European citizen, and it is also an affront to human dignity and to democratic values. Despite hopes of change in Iran, the situation is getting worse. The regime's support for terrorism is increasing; executions are more numerous, as are human rights violations. In order not to disrupt relations with the regime, some argue that tacit diplomacy should be applied in the case of Djalali. This quiet diplomacy is, until now, ineffective. That is why the resolution that we are going to deal with today is so important. From the European Parliament, we say directly to the Iranian regime: release Ahmadreza Djalali, respect human rights, abolish the death penalty.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, while human rights in Iran are systematically violated, European leaders have most attention for the rescue of the JCPOA. Preserving the nuclear deal is important, but we must be able to address human rights as well as Iran’s toxic role in the Middle East. Dual nationals are used by Iran’s rulers as political pawns. They suffer in prisons without access to lawyers, doctors and EU diplomats. Often they are forced into confessions, after which torture and possibly the death penalty can follow. The fact that EU citizens are seen as only Iranians when they still have that nationality tells us all we need to know about the countless Iranians and how they are treated unjustly in prisons. We call for their release, and we appeal to High Representative / Vice-President Mogherini and Member State leaders not to allow talks on the nuclear agreement to overshadow our responsibility to address the grave human rights violations in the Islamic Republic of Iran.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today, we are discussing and voting on an unusual resolution, which is very personal in nature – we are admonishing for imprisoned persons with dual EU-Iranian citizenship. In the beginning, it was only Mr. Djalali, whom we have reprimanded many times, now there are four names there. The issue of human rights has been, is and will be on the agenda of the Delegation for Iran, but I know that not all countries and families agree to such public interventions. I hope that our resolution will help those mentioned there. But this happens at a special time. The European Union has more responsibility to stop the nuclear arms race in this most "volcanic" region in the world than when the United States was a party to the agreement. How do we sustain the transatlantic alliance in the age of President Trump on how to save the nuclear agreement without giving up human rights? This is our real challenge.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, despite our goodwill and engagement, Iran continues to be a massive violator of human rights. According to Amnesty International, in 2017, the country was responsible for a majority of the world’s executions that year. In late 2017 and January 2018, massive demonstrations happened. Then thousands of Iranian people – young people mostly – were imprisoned, including dual nationals of both EU Member States and other democracies’ nationalities. A number of them have also died in the most suspicious conditions, including well-known Iranian-Canadian, Professor Emami.  We have to appeal to High Representative Mogherini to take the floor and put this topic high in the agenda in her dialogue with Iran. We have to support the role of the UN Special Rapporteur on Iran and Iran’s authorities allowing him entry to the country and continuation of the report.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, it is an emergency colleague who has seen these recent photos saying it: Ahmad Reza Jalali is barely recognisable, he looks dying. Already last January, I questioned in this Chamber the High Representative on the fate of this Swedish-Iranian, professor at the VUB in Brussels, sentenced to death after a farce of trial and under a false pretext, two years ago. He has since languished in a cell, waiting for his execution, fortunately, under international pressure, but without access to either a lawyer or a doctor. Many dual nationals are in the same situation, such as british-Iranian researcher Abbas Edalat, who was arrested a month ago without charge. What are we going to do? At a time when Donald Trump is threatening to pull out of the nuclear deal, Iran needs the European partner that we are more than ever. That is where we have a weapon, rather a lever, Commissioner, to force Iran to release all these political hostages.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In 2017, 507 people were executed in Iran. This represents 60% of all confirmed executions in the Middle East and North Africa. Iran, as usual, comes second behind China in the number of death sentences imposed. Iran is a country where it is well known that human rights are not respected by the Persian regime. It is a country where freedom of expression, freedom of religion, freedom of association, but also environmental commitment can lead to innocent people being tortured and sentenced to death on all sorts of unclear grounds. In recent years, the country has intensified the arrest of civil society activists, human rights defenders, environmentalists and political activists. Many are the cases that Amnesty and others have drawn attention to over the years. Today I would like to pay particular attention to the Swedish researcher Ahmadreza Djalali, who has been imprisoned for two years in one of the world's most dangerous prisons, Evin Prison. It is a prison notorious for its torture-like practices and where it has been reported that several prisoners have been tortured to death. For two years, Djalali has been away from his family and had little contact with the outside world. In January this year, he was sentenced to death on charges of espionage, to which many people with dual citizenship suffer. Djalali has lost upwards of 25 kilos in the last six months. His health has drastically deteriorated, but he is denied medical care, and I therefore appeal to the Persian authorities to guarantee Djalali the right to his lawyer and medical treatment – in addition to the death sentence must be lifted immediately and that he should be released and given the opportunity to go home to Sweden.  There is no death penalty that can be justified. The death penalty is rather a crime in itself. It is a crime that we in this House have a duty to pay attention to, for all those whose voices have already been silenced or in danger of being silenced.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the How Iran deals with dual nationals, the so-called EU-Iranians, is a huge scandal. As we now know, there are many cases where people are imprisoned, tortured, threatened with death, have no legal assistance. We must state quite clearly that human and civil rights are being trampled underfoot. Although the EU is, of course, on the Iranian side on the anti-nuclear issue and supports it, because it must be about nuclear disarmament in the region, we must not make the mass violation of human rights a secondary issue.  That is why, as a group, we call on Mrs Mogherini to take immediate action. First of all, we have to say how many people who are in detention here really do, and we need to find ways of finally releasing these detainees. The EU must ensure that its citizens are safe, no matter where. If Iran wants to establish normal relations with the EU – economic contacts, for example – then the security of our citizens must also be guaranteed. You cannot have the one without the other. The brutal and human-rights justice system in Iran must be brought to an end. The human rights dialogue with Iran needs consequences – we will not let go.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I wish to draw attention to two British citizens in particular held in Iran: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe and Kamal Foroughi. I will not discuss details of the cases due to the sensitivity. I would just say that Iran must start behaving in a more reasonable way, with respect for other countries and their citizens, if it wishes to be taken seriously and treated with respect by the rest of the world. The release of these British citizens would be a very welcome first step in that direction towards re-engagement with the world and a more sensible, reasonable approach.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, this is not the first time that we have expressed concern about the state of human rights in Iran. It is unacceptable that cases of unfair trials affecting citizens with dual EU-Iranian citizenship continue. These cases violate international agreements and undermine confidence in the development of common relations. We must ask the Iranian authorities to ensure fair trials and to release the wrongfully convicted and imprisoned. On this occasion, it should be reiterated that Iran should allow the UN Special Rapporteur to visit as soon as possible. I am concerned about reports from human rights organisations. We have little information about these cases, but they are the image of a regime that persecutes and takes away the fundamental human rights of its own citizens. It is important that we are the one to draw attention to these cases and to make an urgent and repeated appeal to respect for human rights in Iran.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Stylianides, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent We stand here and demand loud and clear that Ahmadreza Djalali's death sentence be overturned, that he be allowed to come home to Sweden to his family, and that Kamran Ghaderi, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, Abbas Edalat be released immediately. Another very urgent case is Ramin Hossein Panahi, only 22 years old, sentenced to death in a grossly unfair trial. Release him and the others immediately. The human rights situation in Iran is very serious. As a party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Iran has obligations. Nevertheless, arrests of activists and human rights defenders have increased during the current presidency. The EU has an important role to play in engaging not only with the important nuclear agreement but also for human rights in Iran. We must always stand up to the death penalty and we must always safeguard human rights.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! Iran has long played a dangerous game, using the threat of developing nuclear weapons to make the world look the other way. It is about the terrorism they are committing against their own citizens, it is about the terrorism they are spreading in the region and throughout the world, and it is about the general instability throughout the Middle East, which is very much the source of Iran.  Unfortunately, the Iranians have also, for far too, and for far too long, made us look the other way with regard to human rights violations in Iran, because the greater threat of a nuclear power in the world has been at the forefront of effectively opposing Iranian human rights violations. This is the situation that brings us to our debate today, which, in my view, has an overly narrow focus but, after all, still has a very central and important focus, namely the issue of dual nationals who are imprisoned in absolutely appalling conditions in Iranian prisons.  I think it could have been extended to cover all iranian citizens who are prosecuted every single day because of their political beliefs or political views or even their sexuality, but we have taken a good first step. I hope that here in the European Parliament we will start to put a more critical focus on Iran and its actions in the world, and not just focus on the Iran nuclear deal.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Mr President, today at least fourteen dual nationals and foreigners are imprisoned in Iran. Some, as you said, are sentenced to death. I am thinking in particular of Ahmad Reza Jalali, who is well known and appreciated in our country, but also of all others. What did they do? No one knows. Trials in Iran are shams, confessions are most often obtained under torture and on unverifiable charges. In reality, in Iran, justice is nothing more than a repressive instrument of the theocratic dictatorship of the mullahs. The European Union is rightly trying, and I support its efforts, to save the international nuclear agreement with Iran. This is no reason to turn a blind eye to the violations perpetrated permanently in this country, not only against the binationals, but also against all Iranian citizens who disagree with the clerical dictatorship in place. We demand the immediate and unconditional release of all unjustly detained dual nationals and demand the release of all Iranian citizens unjustly convicted and imprisoned. To fail to do so is to be complicit in the abuses of a dictatorship.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Mr President, as has been said, the effort to save the nuclear agreement cannot overshadow the protection of human rights, because this protection is one of the constitutional foundations of the European Union. Human rights are not traded. How can we believe in respecting the nuclear agreement with the European Union when Iran does not respect the citizens of the European Union. Unfortunately, Iran only confirms that it is a country that does not want to respect fundamental human rights, executes hundreds of people a year, the transition to Christianity is punishable by 10 to 15 years in prison. Citizens of the European Union are condemned in Iran on the basis of forced confessions. Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe has been held in an Iranian prison for more than two years. In the case of European Union citizens imprisoned by Iran, the European Union must make use of all possibilities and achieve the release not only of Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe, but of everyone others.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation of the multiple cases of detention of dual nationality citizens, which many of my fellow Members have already described in specific cases, is indeed very alarming in Iran.  The serious conditions of these detentions and the treatment during interrogations are something totally unacceptable. It is essential that the Iranian authorities act urgently and in cooperation with the embassies of the Member States of the European Union and with all the other European institutions in Tehran, in order to deal with all these cases, the cases of these detainees, with the aim of freeing them. It must be reiterated that, in accordance with international law, it is necessary to guarantee a defence in which the accused can choose his own lawyer, and above all to ensure a fair and equitable trial. I also believe it is essential that the dialogue between the European Union and Iran on respect for human rights should be pursued in all possible forums, and that crucial issues such as the death penalty and freedom of expression should continue to be addressed. That is why I believe it is essential that the commitments made with the agreement on the joint global action plan are continued and respected, especially in view of the possible impact of international cooperation on the internal situation and the human rights situation in Iran.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, please take a look. This is Ahmadreza Djalali, guest lecturer at the Free University of Brussels. A husband and a father of two who has always worked for man and science. Two pictures of the same man: after two years in an Iranian cell barely recognizable, a shadow of himself, and he is counting on our help. Fearing economic reprisals, Iran's leaders keep Ahmadreza and other European detainees alive, but releasing them would result in internal loss of face. This hypocrisy creates a hopeless agony for Ahmadreza and his family. As the European Union, we must not be blind to this dark reality. Iran is and remains a theocracy that flirts with the West but has no intention of deviating from its dictatorial course. The EU's aspiration for stability must not make us look the other way when it comes to human rights, even in the wake of the United States' withdrawal from the nuclear agreement.  I call on all European leaders to strongly condemn the mistreatment of European detainees and to ask for their release in any consultation, any contact with the country.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: – Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, the situation with prisoners in Iran who also have European citizenship is the best indicator of the general state of human rights and the situation in Iranian prisons. And it is not difficult to assume that the situation with prisoners who do not have double citizenship, and such a majority, is even more difficult.  After massive protests in January, when 5,000 people were arrested and 14 died in prisons under suspicious circumstances, unrest in Iran continues. In recent months, professors, truck drivers, demonstrators during May Day celebrations have expressed their dissatisfaction with the position in Iran, and in the town of Kazerun, in the third month of this year, three protesters were killed and several injured and imprisoned.  Therefore, any deepening and expanding of relations with Iran, the development of these relations, must be accompanied by an improvement in the situation of prisoners and the situation in Iranian prisons and, in general, the human rights situation in Iran.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, of special concern today is the Swedish-Iranian researcher Ahmadreza Djalali, sentenced to death. There at least 14 other persons of dual citizenship who have been persecuted. In fact, Iran has intensified arrests of civil society activists, human rights defenders and journalists. We call for the immediate release of all of them – but calling is not enough. On Iran, I think we need a similar approach to that proposed in our next resolution on Saudi Arabia. First, introduction of targeted measures against individuals responsible for grave human rights violations, and second, providing active support for civil society groups and defenders of human rights. I would like here to extend our sympathy and support for the Iranian people who have, since the end of last year, repeatedly demonstrated for social and political rights. If we are serious about our own values, it is our first duty to be actively on their side in their quest for civil liberties, human dignity and democracy. (Applause)

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Mr President, the nuclear agreement with Iran, which we would like to see maintained despite the attitude of the United States, does not allow everything. On the issue of human rights, the Iranian government's behaviour is not in line with the international pact on civil and political rights, of which it is a party.  The issue that concerns us today is that of the binationals. The European Union cannot accept that six dual nationals do not have access to the embassy of the European country on which they depend or to the embassy of another European country. Nor can it accept that they do not have access to a lawyer, that they are imprisoned without evidence and without trial because they are simply human rights activists, ecology activists or political activists.  We must therefore demand the release of the incarcerated dual nationals and call for more cooperation from Iran in the human rights protection mechanism, particularly in the context of the high-level dialogue between the European Union and that country.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, the situation in Iran is, in my view, absolutely intolerable. Iran supports terrorist groups, consistently violates human rights en masse. The number of executions of its own citizens is at the top of the world rankings. We see citizens protesting in Iran and then disappearing and never appearing again. I think that this regime deserves unequivocal condemnation and pressure from the international community. Iran must respect dual nationality, and we must speak up, especially in this situation where the United States of America has withdrawn from the nuclear agreement. The situation is more advantageous for us to some extent, we can use it as leverage. Please speak out consistently to protect human rights, we will call on the Institutions of the European Union to defend these human rights in the negotiations with Iran. Of course, I call for the release of the unjustly punished.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Stylianides, with enormous difficulties and forced by the dramatic position taken in the change of white house guard by the United States, the European Union has done the right thing, diplomatically up to the nuclear agreement with Iran, of which Member States of the European Union are part. But at the same time, he has to redouble his diplomatic efforts to face off for European citizens with dual nationality — three Britons, two Swedes, one Austrian — who are suffering from this hell in Iran: convicted in secret trials without consular assistance, without medical assistance, without the assistance or presence of non-governmental organizations that might be providing assistance, completely ignoring the linkage of the Vienna Convention , international law as regards the situation of prisoners.  The European Union must ensure diplomatically the release of European citizens with dual nationality. That has to be the counterpart to the firm policy it is up against, including the denial of visas and restrictions on Iran adopted on April 12.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, in recent weeks the Iranian people have bravely continued their protests and uprisings. We have seen unprecedented a workers’ protest on 1 May; a teachers’ protest on 10 May; the Baluchis in Zahedan on 20 May; massive protests in the city of Kazerun, where four people were shot dead by security forces on 17 May; lorry drivers who had been on a nationwide strike in more than 200 cities all over Iran for more than a week. People are demanding their rights in Iran, but there is almost no mention of these uprisings and protests and human rights of the Iranian people by our EU institutions or our EU officials. Instead of focusing only on the nuclear deal, we need to listen to the people in Iran who are fed up with the dictatorship. They want this regime to go, and they deserve our attention.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, many dual nationals are currently detained in Iran without due process, including two Brits: Abbas Edalat and Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe. All these cases have their heart-breaking details. I want to specifically mention the case of Nazanin, who took her toddler to Iran to celebrate Nowruz with family in 2016. She was convicted of plotting to overthrow the Iranian Government and now faces new, vague charges. Nazanin is innocent, and she is missing her daughter’s childhood. She is only allowed to see her daughter for 90 minutes a week. I have been in touch with her family, and they appreciate this Parliament’s decision to call for the release and fair treatment of EU-Iranian dual nationals. While we debate these arrests of dual nationals, we must also highlight that these actions are part of a wider crackdown on freedom of assembly in Iran. I urge the External Action Service to firmly and collectively engage their Iranian counterparts, echoing the message of this resolution that we debate today. They must call for the release of all those arbitrarily and unfairly-detained as well as imprisoned human rights defenders. We have to do everything we can to bring Nazanin and her daughter home.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the With Iran, we are facing a regime that, with all brutality, stands for half of all death sentences in the world – against all eu human rights and values, according to Amnesty International. We face a brutal dictatorship which is responsible for half of all death penalties in the whole world, against all human rights and values of the EU. Young women and men are protesting for freedom and democracy in the streets of Iran. It is our duty as European politicians to support these people. We must stop looking at the nuclear treaty and treaties at all times. We have to stop only looking for the nuclear agreement and the business we are chasing ahead. So it is clear that we have to stop our policy. We also face Iran with a regime that threatens the whole peace in the world by trying to extinguish Israel. We must stop supporting this regime. Hezbollah and Hamas must be cut off from Iranian funding. Let us stop the Iranian regime today!

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the recent uprising in Iran led by women gives hope to all of us who believe in the possibility of a free Iran, including freedom for the Anglo-Iranian mother Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, who has been imprisoned in Iran for more than two years now on trumped-up charges. The complete disregard by the Iranian authorities of her right to a fair trial and to consular assistance is appalling. It is equally appalling to see how in Europe, governments – including the British Government – have failed to address her case in a proper manner. As Nazanin remains jailed and separated from her family, I urge the High Representative to act on her behalf to urge the Iranian authorities to immediately and unconditionally release her, as well as the four other EU-Iranian dual nationals. With the Iran nuclear deal now weakened by the United States, it is more important than ever to continue to fight for human rights in Iran. Normalised relations with Iran will come through upholding our highest standards in terms of human rights, as well as by standing by the deal that the European Union helped to negotiate. (Applause)

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, in recent years, behind closed-door trials and arbitrary arrests of Iranian-European citizens in Iran have continued, not to mention the excessive number of executions. Since 2015, the Revolutionary Guard has arrested 30 people with a second passport, most for alleged espionage, of which, of these thirty, nineteen have nationalities from European countries, as you well know. Ladies and gentlemen, the fact that the ayatolleregime does not recognise the status of dual nationality puts these citizens in a situation of particular vulnerability, since they do not even have the possibility of receiving consular assistance. In addition, their lawyers and family members claim that the Revolutionary Guard is using them as a bargaining chip in international relations and as a way to discourage foreign investment in that country. Commissioner, while trying to save the comprehensive plan of joint action in 2015 and neutralise the extraterritorial effects of US sanctions, cannot but press the supposedly moderate President Rohani to deliver on his election promise of greater respect for the civil and political rights of his citizens, including those who are also European citizens.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Union is aware of a number of cases of dual nationals imprisoned in Iran and regularly raises them with the Iranian authorities. We call for their release on humanitarian grounds, we ask for appropriate legal counselling and for adequate medical care to be provided to those in need. Given that primary responsibility for consular protection of European Union citizens abroad lies with their Member State of origin, European Union action is always coordinated and done at the request of the Member States and/or the respective families. In this vein, we will continue to closely follow the situation on the ground and use every opportunity to discuss the issue of dual nationals with the Iranian authorities. When in April 2016 the European Union negotiated a joint statement with Iran on the future of our relations, the High Representative / Vice-President said very clearly that human rights had to be an integral part of our engagement. We have established a high-level dialogue with Iran, which is the framework in which all issues are discussed, including human rights. I wish to underline that the European Union has never refrained from raising human rights issues in our contacts with the Iranian authorities. We have constantly called for the respect of human rights, both in public statements and in particular in private conversations.
