In 2016, during the European Union-Iran High-Level Dialogue, the European Union had a first direct exchange with interlocutors from the Iranian judiciary on human rights in more than 10 years. The second meeting took place in Tehran in November 2017, and again, a number of issues were raised, including the death penalty, women’s rights and conditions in the Iranian prisons. Beyond our bilateral engagement, we have been active in multilateral for a, where we supported both the work of the UN Special Rapporteur and the UN Resolution on the situation of human rights in Iran. We have been carrying out démarches and issuing public statements whenever there were major violations in Iran. We will continue to do so, and we will also continue our informal discussion on human rights to progressively address our concerns through this channel. We feel there is openness also on the Iranian side to engage constructively, even if this means discussing difficult and potentially contentious matters.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Thursday, May 31, 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. I am convinced that, despite the delicate moment, it is necessary to 'normalise' our relations with Iran, which means treating it, no more and no less, in the same way as we do with all the other countries, without suffering external pressure or influence. We must therefore not be afraid to confirm our support for the nuclear agreement and to see, as there has been some progress, with regard to the human rights situation. At the same time, however, we must condemn the repression of Iranian citizens with dual nationality. The case of Ahmadreza Djalali, a Swedish-Iranian citizen and former researcher at the University of Novara, who was arrested while in Iran for seminars, forced to sign a confession and sentenced to death on charges of espionage, is emblematic. Djalali is just one, of the many who are suffering the same unacceptable abuses. Dear Iranian friends, we ask you to help us to help you: it is important that our relations remain strong in this period of uncertainty, but this cannot and must not be at the expense of the most basic respect for human rights. Free Djalali and all those who have been wrongly arrested and let us prepare ourselves, together, to face the difficult challenges that the near future will undoubtedly set us.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. – Many members of the European Parliament are concerned about the situation of human rights in Iran. More than half of the executions in the world take place in Iran. Women have been beaten up, humiliated and arrested in public for refusing to comply with strict rules on compulsory wearing of the veil (hijab). In late December 2017 and January this year, nationwide anti—government protests and uprisings shook the country and covered 142 towns and cities in all the 31 provinces of Iran. Thousands were arrested during the protests and 14 individuals have died in custody following their arrest. The top leaders of the Islamic Republic of Iran have professed a leading role for the opposition PMOI in organising the protests. The protests have continued in Iran. For example, on 16 May in the city of Kazerun, government forces opened fire on protesters, leaving 4 dead and many more wounded. Also, truck drivers all over Iran have gone on a strike since 22 May, which has paralysed the country. I believe we should make human rights a condition for our relations with Iran. Human rights and recognising the uprisings in Iran should be our priority, instead of being obsessed with the nuclear deal.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – The continuation of the detention of persons of dual European and Iranian nationality, following unfair trials, must cease immediately and the detainees must be released immediately. The Iranian authorities must be held accountable for the violation of their rights. It is very serious that there are still cases of death sentence, which has long been banned in Europe, without exception. Iran must ban the death penalty, and until it legislates to stop all executions. It must also stop using arbitrary detention in respect of dual nationals as well as foreigners and provide procedural safeguards to ensure fair trials. President Hassan Rouhani has appointed a committee to investigate recent deaths in detention centres in Iran, but so far no information from the investigation has been made public. Independent investigations of arrests, as well as allegations of excessive use of force during recent protests in Iran, are vital for people to have minimal confidence in state institutions and to stop the brutal violation of civil and political rights.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on women's rights defenders in Saudi Arabia (2018/2712(RSP)).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, like many around the world, I reacted with optimism to Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman Al Saud’s ‘Vision 2030’ reform agenda in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, and lifting the ban on women drivers is, of course, a very good start. Positive steps towards the protection of individual rights are being made, and I welcome these wholeheartedly. However, if Saudi Arabia wishes to cement its position as an influential key actor in the Middle East and North Africa region, the process of judicial reform must be in line with accepted international standards. That’s why it is deeply worrying that this month has seen a wave of arrests of women’s rights activists whose names have not been publicised and whose rights to communication with their lawyers whilst in prison have not been upheld.  The world will be watching whether the Crown Prince will hold fast to his reform agenda and prove that his desire for greater freedom for his people is a genuine one. For all Saudi Arabian citizens, I sincerely hope that this is the case.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Since mid-May, seven women and four men have been arrested in Saudi Arabia for their commitment to women's rights. Four of the women were released a few days ago. They have campaigned against extreme discrimination against women and called for the abolition of the ban on women driving, which is now to be lifted on 24 June, according to the King's decree. Women in Saudi Arabia continue to be denied basic human rights. They depend on the consent of a male guardian if they want to travel, work or marry.  The cautious reforms of recent months have so far remain window-dressing policy. The recent arrests are an expression of increasing repression against critics and completely unacceptable. The activists must be released immediately and unconditionally. It is shameful that the EU's foreign affairs envoy, Mr Mogherini, has not yet publicly called for her release. If King Mohammed bin Salman is serious about his announced reforms, all detained human rights defenders must be released immediately. This includes Raif Badawi, a Sakharov Prize winner who was sentenced to ten years.  European car companies will also benefit from the lifting of the ban on women driving in Saudi Arabia. I call for them, too, to make a consistent and audible commitment to the rights of their future customers.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the lifting of the driving ban on women and the desire to change the rules of male mentoring are just some of the promises that Saudi King Mohammed bin Salman has made to the protagonists of world diplomacy, including the European Union. Important commitments, of course, but they have nevertheless proved to be simply mirrors for larks. Because, as the young king presents himself to the world showing Saudi Arabia as the locomotive of progress in the Middle East region, the human and civil rights situation follows tracks that lead in a different direction. The mentoring system regulates Saudi society, preventing women from carrying out the simplest actions themselves, and gender-based violence is not a recognised crime. A picture, therefore, in strong contradiction to the country dashed by the sovereign's promises, but also contradicts the role that this country plays as a member of the Committee on the Status of Women at the United Nations. For all this, I call on the Saudi authorities to turn words into deeds, not to deceive public opinion. I call for the system of male mentoring to be abolished so that Saudi women can enjoy their rights, including sexual and reproductive rights. Finally, I appeal to the King: that the Sakharov Prize winner, Raif Badawi, be released from prison for expressing his views, and all other human rights defenders who are in the same situation.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank you, I think that it does not happen very often, that we are negotiating a resolution here so long and that we will spend so much time on it. I think it is important to say that we have really thought about every paragraph that is mentioned in this resolution, because the situation in Saudi Arabia is not simple and I think it needs to be seen in some context. Personally, I would like to comment on the human rights violations of women in Saudi Arabia by this resolution. I am glad that we have managed to negotiate a resolution with relatively workable compromises. Saudi Arabia is a major player in the relations between the European Union and the Middle East, so we must not overlook the situation where the international obligations to which Saudi Arabia itself has committed itself to the protection of human rights and the protection of women's rights are being violated. On the other hand, I want to applaud the huge progress that Saudi Arabia has made in recent months, as women's rights are continuously strengthened and , from our point of view, huge reforms have taken place. The resolution expresses quite fundamental concerns about the detection of several women and men who have protested in the area of human rights. I think it is important that Saudi Arabia thoroughly investigates and explains these cases and that it sends a clear signal to the international community that it wants to make significant progress in the area of respect for human rights. The right to a fair trial, the right of access to a lawful court, the right of defence and other rights must also be respected in Saudi Arabia.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, despite charm offensives by Mohammed bin Salman, Saudi Arabia is showing its true colours by arresting prominent women’s rights activists, right when the driving ban that these women fought for is promised to be lifted. Then, state-linked media labelled these women as traitors, and they have since been charged with serious crimes. This sends a chilling signal to all human rights defenders in the kingdom and beyond. It is also a wake-up call for those who still needed it. It will be unsustainable to repress the population and women in such a systematic way, as happens in Saudi Arabia every day. The promise of reforms under the 2030 strategy has been tarnished, and we should hold Saudi Arabia to its acts, not just its beautiful promises made alongside celebrities in foreign countries. The release of women’s rights activists should be the first step and would be a first important step, as we urge, to grant basic rights to all people in Saudi Arabia. We will not be impressed with some small gestures.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in a context of continued persecution of human rights defenders, since 2013 the Saudi authorities have been systematically arresting, targeting and condemning civil society activists, in an attempt to further restrict freedom of expression in the country. Although Saudi Arabia has promised a series of attempts at reform aimed at relaxing restrictions on women, this is nothing more than a smokescreen, a kind of illusion of freedom from a government that acts on the basis of totally opposite principles and assumptions. These assumptions actually hamper or risk rendering the effectiveness of these reforms ineffective. It is not surprising that it is precisely prominent bloggers and activists who have been imprisoned for driving. We are not at all surprised in a state like Saudi Arabia. Perhaps the fear is that women will start counting something in one of the most misogynistic and retrograde states on the planet, and that would be a clear threat to power in Saudi Arabia.

name: Soraya POST
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in Saudi Arabia, women are treated as less than human. It is good news that women can now start to enjoy some of their most basic human rights which they have long been denied, such as launching their own business and driving. But, without a fully-functioning democracy, even these freedoms cannot be enjoyed. 11 women’s rights activists are right now detained in prison – the very same who have been tirelessly campaigning against a ban on driving and the repressive and inhuman guardian system. The human rights defenders must be released immediately and the reforms in Saudi Arabia must go further and faster. Why should women wait to enjoy their basic human rights? It is time for Saudi to understand that without women, you are nothing, so please release these women from prison so they can enjoy their basic human rights. (Applause)

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Saudi Arabia is a Muslim country whose law is based on Sharia law. Practicing religions other than Islam is a crime. Women's rights in Saudi Arabia do not actually exist. It is the last country in the world to give women the right to vote – it was only in 2015 that women who were victims of gang rape were sent to prison. Underage girls are used as a kind of means of payment when paying debts. Saudi women themselves cannot continue to go to the doctor, and for disobedience they can be imprisoned in the so-called women's room throughout their lives. The recent arrests of women's rights activists confirm that the proposed reforms are, in fact, just a soap of the eyes. Let us rebuke loudly, as the European Parliament, the rights of women in Saudi Arabia, because they do not really exist.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, the fact that we are again gathered here in this House to discuss the human rights situation in Saudi Arabia is appalling. We see a well-funded media campaign aimed at demonstrating as if reforms in the country were being implemented one after another. However, the reality is different. In fact, we see a crackdown on women’s rights and human rights activists taking place. Since 15 May only, already 12 women’s rights activists, including those promoting women’s right to drive, have been arrested, defamed and labelled as traitors. The aim is to silence all of those who openly speak out. This cannot go on. Here, today, we call on the Saudi authorities to put an end to the treatment of Saudi women as second-class citizens and immediately and unconditionally release all of them. I also call for the immediate freeing of Raif Badawi, Sakharov Prize laureate, who has been imprisoned for solely exercising his right to freedom and expression.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Wahhabi Saudi Arabia is undoubtedly a repressive regime. Their treatment of women and abuse of their rights is backward and uncivilised. What is worse, they seek to export their medieval values worldwide. I consider the best way to counter this is to export our values of freedom through trade. Free market capitalism has always been the gateway to free peoples, as we saw with the collapse of the Soviet Union. Any suggestion that the 6 000 UK firms exporting over GBP 7 billion worth of goods to Saudi be stopped is folly. What we must do is increase our trade and expose the Saudi people to the values of freedom through free markets. Trade sanctions and embargoes, as with other parts of the world, is merely cutting our nose off to spite our face. Freedom is an unstoppable, uncontrollable ideal. No repressive state or religious superstition can ever defeat it in the long run. Its promotion is our greatest weapon against the forces of darkness and repression, many of these forces so well highlighted by the regime in Saudi and the ideals that they export through their funding of mosques in other parts of the world. It is crucial that we stay strong, free and open, and that we expose people to our values, to our trade, to the free market. Through that, civilisation and free peoples will undoubtedly follow.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, your motion for a resolution highlights the incarceration and arbitrary convictions of several peaceful human rights activists and women."  You also point out, quite rightly, the violence that targets religious minorities, and I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the Christians of this country who are silently subjected to this violence. You then call on the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia to abandon what you call the culture of patriarchy, which puts women under guardianship. Don't be afraid of words! The problem here is Islamic law, Sharia law, which is not only the norm in Saudi Arabia, but which is also pointing its nose in Europe and seriously beginning to threaten our fellow citizens. You are concerned about what is happening there, but you never mention the threat posed by Saudi Arabia's growing grip in Europe and France, particularly through Islamic networks and the funding of mosques, organizations or associations that are openly Salafist. This resolution is therefore largely incomplete and merely gives the European Union a role as a virgin frightened at the spectacle of arbitrary executions or arrests.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, if Prince Mohammed bin Salman is true to his promise of modernising the country and advancing women’s rights, then a major first step would be releasing all women’s rights defenders and activists who have been arrested and imprisoned in the recent crackdown. Following my visit to the Kingdom last year, I praised the Saudis on the project Vision 2030 and its efforts in reforming, as well as taking positive steps with the lifting of the ban on women driving. I know the country is on a journey to modernisation, but that journey will get more difficult if it takes the regressive steps of arresting and imprisoning women while fighting discrimination. I am also aware that the male guardian system is currently being reviewed and will, hopefully, be reformed very soon, enabling women to act and participate independently in society. Women in Saudi Arabia need their basic human rights to be acknowledged, upheld and enhanced. I believe Saudi Arabia as a country will be a stronger one through its inclusivity, empowerment and participation of women. The more successful nations in the world are the ones who are true pioneers of gender equality.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, women in Saudi Arabia are abused, discriminated against, belittled in every aspect of their lives. It has been said that there is a system of segregation which wants them to be totally subject to the control of men, of a man, whether it be a father, a husband or a brother. It is therefore the task of this Parliament to defend and promote the self-determination of women in every part of the world. So we cannot fail to condemn what is still happening in Saudi Arabia today, we cannot fail to call for the immediate release of the activists fighting for the defence of these women, and for the immediate release, Mr President, of the Sakharov Prize winner Raif Badawi. We cannot fail to call for words to finally be taken into account, and for a breakthrough to finally be put in place which will finally mark an improvement in the conditions of these women.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, those who thought that Prince Mohammed bin Salman's decree allowing Saudi women to lead from 24 June was new evidence of a progressive turning point in the Saudi kingdom of Wahabita saw their illusions quickly undone by the campaign of intimidation against prominent women's rights advocates. Many were threatened with legal consequences if they made this decision, and several of them were even arrested. Ladies and gentlemen, it is important to say in this House clearly and unequivocally that, despite this decree, the situation of the rights of these activists in Saudi Arabia remains a real scandal. They continue, as women, subjected to a patriarchal regime, based on gender inequality, subject to a guardianship system that subjugates them to the authorization of a male family member to study, travel or pursue certain professions, and face an ultrarepressive context that silences any dissenting voice. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is these women who dare to publicly claim human rights and their emancipation. I end by saying that the real reformers of the kingdom are these and not the Saudi Orthodox and ultraconservatives.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I will be very strict on time, because we have the votes at noon and we have another debate, so I recommend that we keep to the timetable.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Mr President, the positive signs given by the Saudi crown prince on the international stage in favour of the emancipation of women in Saudi Arabia are unfortunately contradicted by the behaviour of the State within the country. The Saudi population, which is known to be very connected to social networks, is eagerly awaiting a liberation of morals and gender equality. Despite this, the press and the media, essential to the balance of power, are still not free. We deplore, as many colleagues have said, that Raif Badawi, winner of the 2015 Sakharov Prize, is still imprisoned for crimes of opinion.  The fight for the liberation of women in Saudi Arabia has only just begun. The European Union must weigh for the effective evolution of this country, subject to a patriarchal system of another era that ignores the right of women to be autonomous and to decide freely on their daily lives.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Mr President, the difference in tone of this morning's emergencies shows how not all countries here are treated in the same way by some. There are friendly countries, partners and others.  The letter sent by the Saudi embassy is a piece of anthology. The country is in a phase of massive reforms. Whose act. There is a long way to go to get it out of the Middle Ages, especially for women who still live under the full tutelage of men. Indeed, women will finally have the right to drive. What a breakthrough in 2018! And what to think of when, a few days before this right came into force, women's rights activists are arrested, such as Loujain al-Hathloul, for committing a crime of lese majeste while attending a CEDAW meeting, and are incommunicado. So if Prince bin Salman has a real will for reform, these men and women, including Raif Badawi, our Sakharov Prize, who are not in the service of foreigners, but of freedom, must be released and the prince must stop martyring the Yemeni people.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it was 15 May when Loujain al-Hathloul, a women's rights activist, was brutally removed from her home and dragged into prison, having already been arrested earlier for dadn at the wheel. In complete isolation and without any contact with the outside world, she has been wrongly accused of treason and conspiracy against the country, a serious charge that can lead to years in prison. Like you, others on the same day. Their only fault is that they fought peacefully for the defence of their rights. Where are the highly anticipated promises of reform of the Saudi Crown Prince, which so blatantly many applauded? As long as this is Saudi policy, as long as Raif Badawi is still imprisoned, the Saudi prince's words will be nothing but words, empty and useless words of rhetoric that, frankly, we no longer accept.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, United Nations (UN) human rights officials have warned this week that allegations against six women and three men known to have been taken into custody by the Saudi authorities appear to be very serious and could lead to draconian sentences. Indeed, they could face the death penalty.  The detainees are being held by Saudi authorities at unknown locations, with one woman detained completely incommunicado. If, as it appears, their detention is related solely to their work as human rights defenders and activists on women’s issues, they should be released immediately. These women have been subjected to a smear campaign in the Saudi media, being branded as traitors, which is a very worrying development for women human rights defenders and activists.  These arrests also come amid a PR push by the Saudi State, particularly targeting Western media, that attempts to sell de facto ruler Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman as a great reformer. In reality, the Saudi authorities have increased their repression of activists at home and are continuing their British and US-backed war on Yemen.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, we have dealt with issues relating to human rights violations in Saudi Arabia many times, and I must once again call for the release of the Sakharov Prize winner, Mr Badawi, who is unfortunately still in prison. However, I would also like to applaud the reform course set by the Crown Prince, whether it concerns a driving ban or a restriction on male guardianship. However, I would like to say that by a certain proverb the tree can be recognized by fruit. I am not sure at the moment what the fruit is like in Saudi Arabia now. I think it is important at this point to speak up and to say that we are monitoring this situation, that we are following it very closely and calling on the Crown Prince not only to use words, but also concrete actions. Also on the people specifically released and on the sharp improvement in the human rights situation in Saudi Arabia.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I support the resolution, which I am also co-signing. Human rights violations in Saudi Arabia are on the agenda. There is no freedom of the press, activists cannot express themselves. Above all, there is a systematic suppression of women's rights, which until recently could not even drive a car on their own. There's the process of male custody, as it's called. Women, therefore, in order to make international trips, to have access to care services, to have the right to choose residence and to file complaints, they must first obtain the permission of either the husband, father or brother. It is obvious, then, that this situation in Saudi Arabia cannot continue. There is a systematic violation of women's rights and, of course, the seven activist women mentioned in the resolution have been wrongly accused and arrested. Immediate release of them!

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, dissidents are arrested and tortured in Saudi Arabia, as is unfortunately the case with Sakharov Prize winner Raif Badawi. Those sentenced to death are being executed at an ever-increasing rate and, in general, human rights are being violated. Of course, human rights and women are being violated in ways that have already been mentioned and are an insult, not only to our culture, but above all to our humanism. Officially and hypocritically, the regime announces reforms to grant rights to women. On the other hand, however, in legalistic ways, it is trying to avoid implementing these reforms. This is an unacceptable situation, which must end and that is why the European Union must intervene. If we want to seek and achieve condemnation of this situation and change it, tough decisions will have to be taken. Tough diplomatic economic measures must be imposed against Saudi Arabia and, above all, European countries should be banned from selling arms in that country.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, very contradictory signals come from Saudi Arabia. We have all welcomed some openings of Prince Mohammad Bin Salman, such as the lifting of the ban on women's driving, which will begin on 24 June. But the fact that the very activists who succeeded through their campaigns to bring up this ban have been arrested is a very negative signal. It seems that at least 11 activists, most of them women, have been imprisoned and the European Parliament must demand the immediate release of these activists. Reforms must continue, because the precarious situation of human and women's rights in Saudi Arabia is still intolerable. Saudi Arabia must implement their international human rights commitments and the European Union must make use of all diplomatic and economic formulas to ensure that this is implemented.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we started to follow, immediately after the information was made public, the situation and the developments in the specific case of the arrest of several human-right defenders, including a group of prominent women activists, in Saudi Arabia. The European Union is both surprised and disappointed by these developments. These arrests take place as Saudi Arabia has embarked on a programme of socio-economic transformation and modernisation, and against the background of recent commitments by the Saudi leadership to women’s empowerment. These activists have, for many years, been promoting women’s rights and women’s empowerment in line with the Saudi leadership’s commitments under ‘Vision 2030’. Our delegation in Riyadh was in contact with some of them because, as usual, we support on the ground the cause and the effort of people who try actively to improve human-rights standards in our partner countries. Hence our surprise and disappointment, as these arrests are in direct contradiction with the messages we have heard – and have welcomed – from the Saudi leadership in recent times. Moreover, the arrests happened one month before the end of the female driving ban, expected to enter into effect on 24 June, a ban against which most of these women and men had campaigned. Adding to our surprise was the severity of the accusations brought against these human-rights defenders and the defamatory campaign conducted against them in the media – before any legal action had been started and therefore against the principle of presumption of innocence. The European Union immediately sought clarification from the authorities on the circumstances around the arrests and notably on the specific accusations brought. We are waiting for a reply from the authorities and we will persist in our diplomatic engagement in order to shed some light on these arrests. The situation is fluid and information is limited. We have noted with satisfaction the release of four of the women who had been arrested, including a 70-year-old, although we understand that new arrests of further human-rights defenders have taken place, after the first wave of arrests on 15 May – thus giving very mixed messages on the overall situation. Recent reforms in Saudi Arabia have allowed women to attend sports events, apply for government jobs, and enjoy the country’s first public cinema screening in 35 years. We are encouraged by these reforms and we hope they will indicate a new pattern in the Saudi commitments. The European Union wants to encourage the authorities to maintain that trajectory, and to continue improving the Saudi social fabric. Setbacks such as those just witnessed are therefore deplorable. The European Union stands ready to support and accompany modernisation efforts in Saudi Arabia, notably those that aim at strengthening human rights and fundamental freedoms. This is the message that the High Representative / Vice-President transmits relentlessly to the Saudi authorities in all her contacts.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Thursday, May 31, 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – The concept of human rights refers to the legal, philosophical and political idea that every human being regardless of gender, ethnic origin, citizenship or religious belief has certain rights – inaliething and universal.  When it comes to women's fundamental rights, Saudi Arabia is one of the leaders in their violation and discrimination against women and girls. Although by its state order the Muslim hereditary monarchy, fundamental human rights, as universal, must be respected. Although the Saudi government has on several occasions promised reforms, they are being implemented in a "snail's step" while women in Saudi Arabia have been treated as second-class citizens.  The women's driving ban is lifted in 2018. Only 38 women are in political office across the country, which has a population of more than 32 million, and were only allowed to run three years ago. Since 2016, physical education for girls in schools across the country has been banned. Saudi laws are rigorous and women are fully summed up under the so-called male guardianship system, since without the permission of a man (wife, father, brother or even underage son) women cannot do some basic everyday things.  It is inadmissible for women's fundamental rights fighters to be arrested because it is not a sign of openness to reform, quite the opposite.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Sudan, in particular the situation of Noura Hussein Hammad (2018/2713(RSP)).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, Noura Hussein Hammad was just a teenage girl when she entered into a forced marriage with a man who brutally raped her. Tragically, she stabbed her husband to death in self-defence and now faces the death sentence for what the Sudanese authorities claim to be a premeditated murder. In the light of these events, I join the one million people currently petitioning for justice for Noura, calling for the rescinding of her death sentence and a free and fair retrial.  As tragic as Noura’s story is, however, it is but one in an ongoing pattern of constant human rights violations, particularly against women, that happens in Sudan on a daily basis. I therefore strongly support today’s resolution urging the Sudanese Government to stand by their international human rights commitments, seriously address the patterns of human rights violations in that country, and outlaw the unacceptable practices of child marriage, forced marriage and violence against women, both inside and outside of marriage.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: author. – Mr President, yesterday we debated a resolution on gender equality and women’s empowerment through EU external relations and today we have another horrible case of clear violation of the rights of women and girls.  The role of the European Union in Sudan raises serious concerns. It looks like the European Union is only concerned with migration flows. However, the EU and individual Member States that cooperate with Sudan have the responsibility to urge the regime to respect human rights, particularly the rights of women and girls, and to call on the Sudanese Government to reform its legal system in accordance with international human rights standards.  My Group is committed to the promotion, protection and guarantee of human rights. We therefore tabled an amendment to highlight how the EU is abandoning its core values in its relations with Sudan and I hope that all the Groups will be willing to support this justified criticism.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, I call on the Sudanese authorities to remove the death sentence on Noura Hussein. This is an inhuman and unjust sentencing of a girl, a child bride who was physically and psychologically abused by her family and raped by her husband. Noura was defending herself from being raped again by a man she was forced to be married to when she was only 16. In its judgment, the court did not take into account forced marriage, rape and other forms of gender-based violence as evidence, so Noura did not even get a fair trial. Marital rape is illegal, child marriage is illegal, violence against women is illegal. Noura was acting in self-defence. She is the victim. She deserves full respect for her right to a fair trial and appeal, in line with international standards, not to be judged to that sentence.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the This month, the international public was shocked by the fate of Noura Hussein Hamad, a young woman from Sudan. As a minor, she was forcibly married by her parents to a man she did not love, and she was repeatedly raped by her husband and relatives. In self-defence, she fatally injured the man, and a court in Omdurman sentenced her to death because, according to the reasoning, there was no rape in the marriage. This verdict, and what has happened to Noura, highlights the situation of many girls and young women in Sudan, but also in many other countries where forced marriage and violence against women in the family are commonplace and more than questionable jurisprudence also covers this. It is our duty to demand justice, respect for the dignity of Noura Hussein Hamad and the annulment of the death sentence. Sudan receives a lot of aid from the EU, despite a questionable and repressive regime. At the same time, we should demand that the Sudanese authorities respect universal human rights.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Mr. President, Nura Hussein was forced to marry at the age of sixteen. Raped, abused and now sentenced to death for killing her husband while she raped her. It's not an isolated case. In Sudan, women may be forced to marry when they are ten years old. They suffer sexual and physical violence, such as lashes for not dressing properly, while those responsible enjoy total impunity. This is the case with a European Union which is said to be a guarantor of human rights and which finances projects of EUR 275 million in development aid, humanitarian assistance and border control operations in Sudan. Forced marriage is one of the most common causes of gender persecution claimed by women like Nura when they apply for asylum in Europe. And they're denied. Women's rights cannot remain second division rights. While denying safe passages for all those fleeing war, misery and patriarchal violence, we pay dictatorships like Sudan to serve as border policemen, perpetuating structural violence against women. We demand that the European Union be consistent with its discourses and condition its funds and trade relations on respect for human rights. From here we demand pardon for Nura and freedom for all Nuras who in Sudan remain oppressed and excluded.

name: Urmas PAET
text: author. – Mr President, it is imperative that Sudan overturn the death sentence on Noura Hussein Hammad, ensure her safety and give her access to psychological help. Hopefully the movement ‘Justice for Noura’ and the international attention this case has been given will help in Noura’s case, but will also spread wider knowledge in Sudanese society about the rights of women and children that need to be upheld. The Sudanese authorities are the ones that need to review and reform the laws in Sudan as regards the rights of women and children. The age of marriage needs to be raised. All cases of gender—based violence and sexual violence need to be prosecuted and their perpetrators held liable. The implementation of laws which already exist must be enforced. Forced marriage and marital rape is a deep-rooted problem in Sudanese society and regarded as something normal. This needs to be tackled at the highest level, starting with the President of Sudan, who should also finally acknowledge the role of the ICC.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, women's rights were on the agenda of the discussions we had in the delegation of the Subcommittee on Human Rights, which travelled to Khartoum in December 2017. I was able, on this occasion, to visit omdurman Prison. Noura Hussein Hammad, whose situation has rightly mobilised the world public, is also in this prison. As my colleagues said, this young woman was forcibly married at just 16 and then raped by her husband with the help of relatives. Noura Hussein Hammad defends her life and dignity, which is why today, behold, she is sentenced to death. Unfortunately, the justice sin of Sudan did not heed the circumstances, which are quite outrageous, which I have mentioned here. I want to insist, as my colleagues have done, on the switching of the sentence received by Noura Hussein Hammad. I recall, first of all, that the European Union has a strong stance on the death penalty. Moreover, under international rules, where the death penalty is imposed against clear evidence of self-defence, it can be equated with arbitrary execution. That is why I ask the officials of Sudan to take into account the requests we are making today, behold, all the political groups in Parliament.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Noura Hussein Hammad was sentenced to death by the Sudanese authorities because she killed her rapist husband. She isn’t the first woman to find herself in this situation, and I fear she won’t be the last. The fact that Noura was forced to use deadly violence to defend herself demonstrates the appalling state of affairs regarding women’s rights around the world. Forced marriage and conjugal rape are two ways in which patriarchy operates and gives power to men over women’s bodies and consciences. Noura was married at the age of 16 against her will and subjected to sexual violence and humiliation. She deserves to have access to a fair and transparent trial that gives her the opportunity to defend herself. As part of the European Union struggle for gender equality, I urge the High Representative to use all the means at her disposal to prevent the Sudanese authorities from executing Noura, who was a victim of sexual violence. She is our sister in the global struggle to end gender-based violence.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the victim of a forced marriage, immobilized by two members of his in-laws, and then raped at the age of 19 by the man to whom she was intended, Noura Hussein Ahmad's fault was not to accept this violence, to resist and to have killed his rapist. His fate deserves our un appealed condemnation. We must save her, by all means, from the death penalty promised by the Sudanese regime. Since Hassan Al-Tourabi, this regime has based its principles on the most radical Islam there is. Many Europeanists are not shocked to see sharia infest our societies, from Molenbeek to Birmingham, from the French suburbs to those of Rotterdam. So much so that in 2004, the French Civil Code had to be reformed to raise the age of the nubility of women in France from 15 to 18 years, to avoid the dozens of forced or arranged marriages, now imposed by mores totally foreign to our civilization. The case of this young woman is only the most dramatic expression of a plan that many of you here pretend to ignore. The forced Islamization of our societies is a reality that we must fight at all costs.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will vote against this resolution and urge everyone to do so, not because I agree with the judgment on Noura Hussein Hammad, because it is probably wrong. But firstly, the European Parliament is supposed to be a right in Europe, not to review the judgments of the courts in Sudan. This is an unacceptable way out of your remit. You have no knowledge or powers to do so. Secondly, you are calling on Sudan to change the court order, which is probably illegal, is a violation of the law. It is unacceptable for the executive to interfere in the activities of the judiciary. Thirdly, in order to reduce the chances of serious treatment, you are instructing Sudan how to reform its country. Why? Fourth: paragraph 2: "... the sentencing of the death penalty on the basis of clear evidence of the defence necessary constitutes arbitrary murder, especially in the case of women." How is it "especially for women"? What does that mean? Is "all animals equal, but pigs are more equal than others"? Why do you value human life on the basis of gender? This is outrageous sexism. That is why I will vote against it.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, sudan's Constitution states that the state protects women from injustice and promotes gender equality. We call on the Sudanese authorities to ensure that this principle is fully applied, and also in compliance with the provisions of the Maputo Protocol, including for the Cotonou Agreements that bind us with the ACP countries – Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific – so that all women can be granted their fundamental rights, so that there are no more cases of marital rape. , which is and remains a form of sexual and gender-based violence. We expect a strong signal from this country, reiterating our strongest opposition to the death penalty in all cases and in all circumstances. Sudan demonstrates to this House and to the international community that rape and gender-based violence run counter to the principles imposed by the Constitution itself. Sudan is showing clemency by saving the life of a young woman, Noura Hussein Hammad, whose life has already been destroyed by the abuses and violence she has suffered.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, when I heard the story of Noura Hussein Hammad, I was deeply hurt because it is not only her who has suffered such cruelty; this cruelty is part of society in Sudan. Our resolution may raise awareness among some of the officials there and may bring to light the atrocities of women’s lives in Sudan, but it will barely diminish the culture of cruelty. Hussein, a girl only 16 years old, suffered too many atrocities inflicted by society, to become a martyr. There is no honour in honour crimes. Hussein suffered extreme loneliness as nobody, not even her family, protected her. What we must do is to show our solidarity and provide assistance to such women in Muslim countries. The culture of cruelty is not a fate. We can change it with difficulty, but still we can make a small change by giving a voice and a face to such victims.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I support the resolution, which I have co-signed. The tragic case of Noura Hussein Hammad highlights the serious problem of forced marriages of women, which exists in Sudan and other Muslim and African countries. The mobilisation of one million of our fellow citizens, who are calling for a fair trial and at the same time for not carrying out the death penalty against Noura, shows a great movement of support. A movement of support, which extends here in the European Parliament. It is a given that this anachronistic and coercive institution of forced marriages, which forced girls as young as ten, twelve, thirteen years old to marry without even wishing to do so, must be stopped and, of course, cannot pass even in Europe but must not apply in certain countries to which it applies. Commissioner, stop giving funds to Sudan.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, poor, young, but above all a woman. To be in Sudan is a bit like a condemnation, a condemnation to be considered as a slave to one's father, one's husband, one's tribe. A chilling but normal condition for Sudanese women and girls, often forced by their parents themselves to marry from the age of ten. Noura was 16 when she was due to marry Abdulrahman, a husband-master who, after raping her with the help of her brothers and cousin, wanted to abuse her a second time. But that day Noura did not bow to the fear of her rapist husband, she reacted to protect her body, but above all her mind from the threat of yet another abuse. Today, however, the price that Noura has to pay for a legitimate defence that has resulted in the death of her oppressor is very much and too high: not only the loss of freedom, but also that of life itself. We call on Sudan to annul the death sentence immediately, taking into account the facts, to raise the age of marriage to 18 and to recognise sexual violence as a crime even within marriage. And we call on the European Union to immediately suspend the funds that are disbursed until that country complies with the minimum of human rights that should be part of any community on this planet.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, we are also discussing Sudan repeatedly here, and it is constantly about the same thing, violations of women's rights, child slavery, child labour, child labour, child marriage, and now we are talking about the maximum penalty. The death penalty for rape, which was objective, the woman said no and no. How many times are we going to do Sudan here? I believe that we must put real diplomatic pressure on this country, and our last possible measure is to limit development aid and devote this money to non-profit organisations that may be active in the area. So, yes, please, let's step up diplomatic efforts. In the time I have left, I would like to strongly condemn what my colleague Sośnierz said here, this is indeed a huge shame what words he has chosen here, and I think that this is as reprehensible as sudan's progress.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the human rights situation in Sudan remains a continuing worry for the European Union. The shrinking space for civil society organisations and restrictions on freedom of expression and assembly remain among the main areas of our concern. I personally raised this issue during my visit to Sudan last October, but the case of Noura Hussein, who has been sentenced to death at the tender age of 19 after being forced into marriage at the age of 16 and raped, brings to the forefront many of the country’s complex and interrelated human rights problems, ranging from sexual violence, child and forced marriage to the continuing use of capital punishment. Consequently, Noura’s story has caused public outcry not only internationally but, more importantly, also within Sudan. Criminal justice systems ought to offer prevention and protection for women and girls against all forms of violence. This is sadly not the case in Sudan. Rape, including by habitual or cohabiting partners, should never be tolerated under any circumstances. Moreover, Sudan’s Personal Status Law, allowing for child marriage without the consent of the intending spouses, needs urgent revision. As reiterated in the local statement issued by the EU on the case, the European Union is opposed to the death penalty under all circumstances and in all cases, with no exception, and aims at its universal abolition. The EU is also concerned at the recent news of attempts by the state security apparatus to intimidate Noura’s defence team, and it calls on Sudan to allow the lawyers to work without fear of reprisals. The EU will continue to make use of the various means at our disposal to promote and protect girls’ and women’s human rights in Sudan. This includes by enhancing the access of women and girls to good-quality education and healthcare services, raising awareness on girls’ and women’s rights among communities, in particular with a view to reducing harmful practices such as female genital mutilation (FGM), as well as supporting women’s economic empowerment through relevant training and micro-credit programmes. The EU also calls on the Government to take the necessary steps to accelerate the ratification and the full, effective and non-discriminatory implementation of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) in order to advance the equal recognition, enjoyment and exercise of all the human rights of women. In this regard, the EU welcomes the Sudanese Government’s intention to ratify the Convention, as announced by the Minister of Justice this week. I would like to assure you that the EU will continue closely to follow the case of Noura and to raise it with the relevant authorities. We will also continue to team up with women’s human-rights defenders and women’s organisations to tackle the underlying causes leading to cases such as that of Noura.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you to the Commissioner, also for being with us most of the morning. The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Thursday, May 31, 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I believe that the penalty must be adequate, proportionate to the crime committed. The Sudanese authorities should take immediate action to ensure proper compliance with human rights standards in the country, to guarantee the right to a fair trial, to review the penalties to be punished for criminal offences and to ensure their adequacy and proportionality in relation to the crime committed. I do not support the use of the death penalty in all cases and in all circumstances. Any inhuman coercion, inhumane, cruelty, torture is unjustifiable. Coercion in the context of marriage is unjustifiable, and the person must be able to decide on this issue himself or herself. I would like to draw particular attention to international commitments. It is therefore essential that Sudan ratifies the Convention against Torture and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women and ensure full compliance with local laws and international obligations.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, I wanted to ask whether it is permissible, under the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, to say what my colleague Markus Ferber said, that the troika should invade Rome and take over the Ministry of Finance. I would like to remind him that the Italian Republic is based on the Constitution born of the Resistance, and that if the European Union were based on the same principles, and not on German ordoliberism, perhaps there would be less Euroscepticism and certainly more social justice. In the meantime, I would ask the Presidency to take note of these statements.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: We take note of your comments and we also have a point of order from Ms García Pérez.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: – Madam President, this very morning the European Court of Justice annulled the decision of the Bureau of this Parliament on sanctions on Mr Korwin-Mikke for insulting and attacking the dignity of European women.  I mean, you can give him back the money, but under no circumstances will he be given back decency and dignity; and that among the values of the European Union is respect for the dignity of women and, therefore, in the face of these positions and in the face of such interventions, this House will have to continue to be a strong defender of women's rights.  (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The judgment has just been made as you say, and will be studied.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to answer. Above all, the European Parliament should defend freedom of expression in its own benches when it instructs the whole world on how it should respect human rights. And punishing someone for the content of a speech in Parliament is absolutely unacceptable. This judgment of the Court is therefore a triumph of freedom of expression and the rule of law in Europe, and I am pleased with it.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: As chairman of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, I read with great dismay the statements by my first Vice-President, Mr Ferber, that the 'Troika in Roma einmarschieren und das Finanzministerium übernehmen sollte'. I think that a person with an institutional office cannot say these things. I find them unacceptable, so let's wait... (Applause from the Chamber) We await a formal apology and a withdrawal of these unacceptable statements, because if not it will be very difficult to cooperate with my Vice-President in the days ahead.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. I was asked by German television: what would happen if Italy was no longer solvent? To which I answered correctly: if Italy is no longer solvent, then the troika would have to take care of it, as is customary in the eurozone. (Interjections and unrest) We were just pleased that the European Court of Justice is strengthening freedom of expression. I hope that this will also apply to everyone in this House. The wording just as it was just chosen by the chairman of the committee was not my wording. There are probably translation problems. I have just pointed out what the mechanism is, as it has been in the past. And I think if you read that in the original language, it is not as bad as it was portrayed in Italy.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the points of order. I would respectfully suggest that this issue is dealt with in committee. I think that is the appropriate place first.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Soraya POST
text: – Madam President, I am absolutely shocked to find that the PPE has asked for a separate vote on paragraph 8 to eliminate the condemnation of Saudi Arabia for the male guardianship system. So my question is: who do you serve, women’s rights or whom?  (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I am sorry. That is not appropriate at this time.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I request that our report, which we have just voted on, be referred back to the ENVI Committee to be the basis for interinstitutional negotiations in accordance with Rule 59(4), Rule 59a and Rule 69d.

name: Ashley FOX
text: – Madam President, I am moving this oral amendment so that Parliament has the opportunity to express its support for the current exemption for stage lighting from the ecodesign regulations. This is vital for small theatres across Europe. I propose that we add a new Recital La as follows: ‘Whereas the existing exemption for stage lighting from the Commission Regulations 244/2009 and 1194/2012 has been an appropriate and effective way to respect the special needs and circumstances for theatres and the whole entertainment industry and should be continued’.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I want to explain why I supported this report, in particular, I believe that consumers would benefit a great deal from this measure. It is a measure against fraudsters in all Member States. I believe that cooperation between states on the market is necessary, and I also expect the European Commission to coordinate this action against cross-border fraud. Rewinding odometers and cheating in this area is hurting consumers across Europe. For this reason, I would like to express my support for the use of EUCARIS, which is already being used by some States. Last but not least, I also consider it important for all Member States to recognise that this manipulation of odometers is a criminal offence, just as the Czech courts have ruled.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report, in agreement with the majority in the European Parliament and the Socialists and Democrats in particular. Unfortunately, mileage fraud is a widespread phenomenon that poses a serious threat to road safety. It also distorts the proper functioning of the internal market and entails unfair additional costs for consumers, insurers, used car dealers, leasing companies and manufacturers alike. A fraud affects 5-12% of cars in national markets, but in cross-border trade it can affect 30-50% of all cars. The economic damage suffered by the eu as a whole is estimated at between EUR 5.6 billion and EUR 9.6 billion. I also consider the database systems used by Belgium and the Netherlands to store mileage data during periodic technical inspections, maintenance and other servicing as a good solution.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I supported this report. In the words of Czech film, which is already a bit classic: "We have had a bit of a problem here." The mischiement is indeed fraudulent behaviour – rewinding the speedometer, misleading consumers, customers, buyers. I am very glad that the European Parliament has agreed quite broadly on the need for new legislation, and other European institutions, particularly the European Commission, need to be pushed to move forward on this matter as well. It is important to protect our consumers, we Members are prepared for this, and now it is important that this single European action is really protected by good examples from abroad, such as the Slovak model, the Belgian model. I definitely want to oppose this fraud by fraudsters, and I think we have a simple, administratively complex action to take across Europe.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Madam President, unauthorised interference with the mileage counter of used cars contributes significantly to the loss of confidence of consumers, second-time car dealers and thus undermines the functioning of the internal market and fair competition. I am also concerned that motor vehicles are not checked on the basis of the kilometres actually used and the handling of the mileage counter in motor vehicles has a negative impact on road safety and negatively affects the environment. I supported the resolution because I believe that technical solutions must be found that will make it more difficult for non-professionals to interfere with odometers. I also consider this important because many Member States still do not provide consumers with the necessary tools to enable them to verify the history of second-hand vehicles. I believe that the elimination of odometer fraud will fundamentally increase safety and certainty in the cross-border purchase of vehicles, thereby reducing the scope of unfair practices, and will also lead to significant benefits for millions of European consumers.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Madam President, I also welcome this approved report on the speeding of cars, because it is a cynical, reckless practice and the fraud of these cars is most paid for by people on lower incomes and from socially weaker backgrounds, especially from Central and Eastern Europe, because it has become a practice of importing cars from Western Europe to us in central European countries. It is estimated that there are up to one million vehicles in Slovakia with a rescheduled counter. However, any attempt to reduce this manipulation is doomed to failure in advance, unless we can sufficiently and better, more effectively capture the manipulation of vehicles imported from Member States of the Union. The solution may be a common database – which is talked about here – of all cars in the European Union, where the number of real mileage will be recorded for various repairs or car manipulations. However, this database must meet all the standards for personal data protection so that it cannot be misused, because such cases are already coming to an end. It is important to apply odometer rescheduled solutions at European Union level, as individual states cannot prevent fraud linked to the cross-border trade in second-country motor vehicles.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, we all want a Europe that protects citizens, and I therefore appreciate the efforts to strengthen the civil protection cooperation mechanism. In view of the increasing and increasing natural disasters in Europe, it is, of course, important that we strengthen this system. So far, it is only voluntary and this voluntary cooperation does not provide sufficiently effective assistance. I therefore welcome the creation of the rescEU system and consider it logical that the European Commission should decide directly on the provision of assistance through the new rescEU capacities. Unfortunately, however, I could not support the draft decision because I strongly do not agree that Erasmus+ should be used for purposes other than youth education and mobility. The committee's draft decision has made this recommendation and the proposal to train civilian workers through this very programme, and I cannot agree with that.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I must start by saying that I was really hesitant about this report because, for example, the Czech Chamber of Deputies made comments on this proposal, disagreed with this proposal and objected to the violation of the principle of subsidiarity. Of course, when it comes to natural disasters affecting the civilian population, we must work to improve the system, there is no doubt about that. On the other hand, if proposals are put into this framework that really have nothing to do with, for example, Erasmus+ educational activities, then I had to raise my eyebrows very high on this.  For me, it was important in my decision that civil protection and its mechanism should really be improved, and that is what we should be doing. Finally, I supported this report with this in mind, and that is why I am also giving this oral explanation.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this resolution because I cannot forget the devastating wave of fires that affected Portugal and other southern European countries last year.  It has been shown that civil protection based only on a voluntary system of mutual assistance between Member States is not enough to respond to the series of natural, environmental or man-made disasters we have faced in recent years.  The rescue system will take the inter-aid capacity further with a Union reserve force that will allow the efforts of the Member States in need to be further. We need to know the resources and articulate the actions, not only in the response of civil protection to the most vulnerable, but also through the commitment to prevention, bringing together the knowledge assets of each Member State to deal with future situations. name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Madam President, the Union Civil Protection Mechanism is a concrete expression of solidarity in various natural or natural disasters where human lives and material values are saved. Individual Member States have their own civil protection mechanisms, but many times more Member States need help to manage disasters quickly. Better cooperation, more technical means, more effective and faster assistance in forest fires, floods or earthquakes, which we have every year in almost every Member State, will be valued by every citizen who receives such assistance. name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab More than twenty billion for the Connecting Europe Facility would seem satisfactory. Unfortunately, this is not the case. name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam Chairman, if I had travelled from the city, by train, where I now live, from Stockholm, it would have taken me approximately six hours. The Western Balkans are part of Europe, and then it's probably necessary to be and to get to that Western Balkans. Thanks a lot.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé ar son na tuarascála seo agus áthas orm é sin a dhéanamh. name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I supported this motion for a resolution. I consider this instrument to be extremely important indeed. name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this resolution on Nicaragua, of which I was one of its signatories, because I believe that this House must clearly and unequivocally condemn the violent repression of the thousands of Nicaraguans who peacefully protested against the very serious deterioration of their living conditions after three consecutive ortegurist mandates, in the shudder of Nicaragua's constitutional principles. name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I voted against the report on a joint staff working document entitled 'Gender equality and women's empowerment: a change in the fate of girls and women in the context of the EU's external relations in 2016-2020', even though it was intended to promote gender equality and women's empowerment by ensuring psychophysical integrity, promoting the economy, social rights and empowering them. text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I voted against because it is ridiculous that the European Parliament is entitled to convert the whole world and infect it with its sexism. text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The youth strategy is due to end this year, 2018. This is a long-term strategy that we can say has not had the desired effect. name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Mr President, I have given my support to the report on the implementation of the European Union Youth Strategy because I think it draws attention to several very important aspects. name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the European Union's youth strategy. text: – In our municipality of Koksijde, Oostduinkerke, we have a magnificent cultural centre, the Casino, known throughout the region because of the excellent programming for young and old.
