name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: author. – Madam President, various cases of sexual abuse and misconduct within international aid organisations have recently come to light. These include the sexual exploitation of Syrian refugees by those delivering aid on behalf of the United Nations and other well-known international organisations. Several countries, including the United Kingdom and the Netherlands, have announced investigations into the funding they provide to these and other international organisations, and that they intend to make measures to prevent similar situations in the future. Through its external financial instruments and the European Development Fund, the EU provides billions of euros in assistance to third countries through international organisations among other channels. I therefore have a few questions for the High Representative on a response from the European Union. First of all, will the Commission or the High Representative order a thorough investigation to determine whether EU funds have financed, either directly or indirectly, the organisations where sexual abuse has been established? Secondly, what is the response by the Commission and the High Representative to the abuse cases that have recently come to light? In order to combat and prevent sexual misconduct within international aid organisations, is there room for guidelines within the EU’s external financial instruments that would make funding strictly conditional upon respect for principles, oversight, guidelines accountability and regular reporting from beneficiaries on this issue? Last but not least, will the Commission and the High Representative consider working with Member States such as the United Kingdom and the Netherlands to set up contact points in third countries including in crisis zones for victims of abuse?

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am really grateful for your initiative to discuss the EU’s response to sexual misconduct in aid organisations. Thank you so much for your questions. Let me respond also on behalf of High Representative / Vice—President Federica Mogherini and my dear colleagues, Commissioner Hahn and Commissioner Mimica. I welcome the opportunity to inform you of developments regarding our collective response and, most importantly, to reiterate our firm position on sexual misconduct. Through our humanitarian work we save lives and through our development aid work we empower people. Our partners play a vital role in our efforts to deliver this much—needed assistance. We expect them – UN agencies, international organisations and NGOs – to abide by the strictest ethical standards, and we do not accept any misconduct that compromises our vital work on the ground. When we became aware of allegations of sexual misconduct by individual staff members in certain organisations, our message was loud and clear: zero tolerance of any form of misconduct and zero tolerance towards any organisation receiving EU funding. We take allegations of misconduct very seriously. Whenever an allegation comes to our attention, we make sure that all procedures are activated. We have in place a number of measures to make sure that EU funding is used properly, according to the highest ethical principles, professional rules and codes of conduct. First, our zero tolerance policy for sexual exploitation and abuse is appended to our contracts with our humanitarian partners. We demand that they have in place effective and coordinated prevention, reporting and response mechanisms. For development funding, contracts include a number of obligations on human rights, labour standards, etc. We are currently working to further reinforce this ethical process, to explicitly address sexual abuse and exploitation. So this is a new effort in order to cover the state of play on the ground, as professional misconduct can lead to suspension and termination of contracts or exclusion from further funding. Our partners are obliged to share information with us on allegations or cases of misconduct in a proactive and fully transparent way. We may of course also refer a case to OLAF for allegations of misappropriation of EU funds. In response to the allegation of sexual misconduct, as soon as we were informed, we acted in a quick and decisive way. First, we reminded all of our partners of their duty to fully comply with the highest ethical and professional standards. This is more than two hundred organisations. We recalled their contractual, but also moral, obligations towards the European Union, and of course towards the people they serve. We asked them to inform us of the concrete measures and procedures they have in place to prevent, detect and address sexual exploitation and abuse. Nearly all partners have replied. Those who have not are informed that we will review our funding to them and even cease our funding and terminate our partnership if needed. So zero tolerance means we take action where needed. In fact, we have put on hold the signature of further contracts with certain organisations. Secondly, we support our partners’ efforts for increased accountability and more effective internal oversight mechanisms. We have strengthened our audits in this regard. The audit programme for humanitarian actions will include the assessment of mechanisms put in place by organisations to prevent, detect and handle cases of sexual abuse and exploitation. Thirdly, we rely on the EU presence in the field in our delegations and in our network of humanitarian offices worldwide – closest, of course, to the beneficiaries, where our humanitarian and development partners operate on a daily basis. Fourthly, we will continue raising awareness about the possibility to report sexual misconduct directly to us, anonymously and in full confidentiality. Finally, we want to address this issue in a comprehensive manner, having everybody on board. We are engaging – since you ask, this is our answer to the question about our collaboration with our Member States. We are engaged with our Member States and other international donors for a thorough review and harmonisation of policies and practices. We want to raise standards whenever and wherever this is required and appropriate. In this context, the Commission joined the safeguarding donor working group, and this issue will be discussed at the G7 ministerial meeting on development. There is no doubt that what has happened in a small number of organisations has tarnished the work of the aid community as a whole. Now it is up to the aid community to show the world that these issues will not be tolerated. Let me be clear: any such misconduct is an abuse of power towards the most vulnerable, the very ones that aid agencies are supposed to help. Our principle is ‘do no harm’, and I intend to keep on pressing this message forward to our partners in the field and at headquarters to all donors and all those in the humanitarian and development community.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, it is important to understand that, in any aid emergency, there is a risk of sexual abuse and sexual exploitation and the abuse of somebody who is in need of assistance. We are gravely concerned that the culture of silence, intimidation and abuse will continue as soon as the media spotlight on this issue begins to dim. The European Union should reconsider funding for Oxfam, one of the largest charity organisations providing assistance in natural disasters, after reports that some of its employees paid for sex while on a mission to assist after the devastating earthquake in 2010. While the UN claims to have had no knowledge of the abusive exploitation of Syrian women, it has been as an ongoing issue for years. It was first reported three years ago by Danielle Spencer, a humanitarian adviser. Spencer was informed about the allegation by Syrian women in a refugee camp in Jordan. Women and girls need to be protected when they are trying to receive food and basic items to live. The last thing you need is a man who you were supposed to trust and supposed to be receiving aid from asking you to have sex with him and withholding aid from you. The ongoing abuse can no longer be ignored. It is horrible enough that these women have to rely on international aid for survival. But for them to fear this aid is unacceptable. Action must be taken to prevent the sexual exploitation of Syrian women and girls. In June 2015, the International Rescue Committee surveyed 190 women and girls from the area and found that 40% had experienced an act of sexual violence when seeking supplies at a distribution centre. This is unacceptable, colleagues. This is unacceptable. Staff who pay for sexual services are incompatible with the values and mission of the aid organisations. This is the real problem. It is systemic, large scale, and simply ugly. We have to fix it.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Contrary to the Istanbul Convention, which deals particularly with domestic violence, it appears that sexual violence is used by high-ranking officials of aid organisations who, instead of helping, engage in sexual perversions even against underage volunteers. The crime agency has warned for 20 years about child abuse in developing countries where, despite the existence of criminal laws, they are difficult to enforce in practice, especially in areas affected by wars or disasters.  In addition to the lack of a legal response, this is evidence of the enormous pathology that arises from the lack of moral principles. The problem of sexual abuse is sometimes referred to in literature as the tip of the iceberg. Organisations such as Save the Children, the British Red Cross and even Doctors Without Borders also confirmed reports of crimes. While sexual harassment in the delivery of humanitarian aid should be combated through criminal standards under national law, the European Union should also stop financially supporting organisations that have participated in such crimes by helping in other ways.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the Commissioner spoke forcefully about the important role of development aid and election observation missions, and the importance that the Commission itself attaches to this kind of political approach and the need to have a voice in the world, in the poorest world, in the world with the most violence, in conflict zones. But it is clear that this news that jumped into the press but could somehow already be known by comments from NGOs or even by comments from certain affected people, because the fact that they were picked up by the New York Times has given them a focus and a light, and we have been very concerned, so much so that we are addressing the European External Action Service on an issue which is, of course, shameful. And so, too, we thank the Commissioner for those words of zero tolerance. Zero tolerance against possible conduct of abuse, reprehensible, election observers and co-operators; Obviously. I believe that we agree on all the groups in this and it is very important that there is also a signal from Parliament for such actions to be verified. Because of these behaviors, in short—also in this House, where we have so many sexist characters, that today, by the way, they are not—it is very good to say that they respond to a patriarchal model. Sexual abuse, sexual harassment, drug-taking, excessive use of alcohol, recourse to prostitution are symptoms of patriarchy, machismo often existing in behaviors that move outside Europe elsewhere. That is why we need to reinforce the ethical aspects with the Code of Conduct for Observers and have a zero tolerance for prohibited behaviors, which are totally prohibited. It is true that they pay righteous for sinners and we must also honor and remember the enormous work of many NGOs. But above all, I would like to conclude, Madam President, by saying that, first, research by the Commission; then sanction in the event of these reprehensible behaviors, but the most important thing is prevention: anticipate.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the EFDD Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We're talking about a pretty incredible story today. There have been cases in which aid workers have sexually exploited refugees – that is, the staff of the NGOs. It is about good people who have turned out to be the opposite of this. First and foremost, the protection orders that the aid workers have committed themselves to are affected. We deeply regret what has happened to the victims. I have confidence in the judiciary that the perpetrators will be held accountable and that justice will be done to the victims.  However, we must also draw political conclusions – including for the fundamental cooperation with NGOs. The NGOs must be imputed to the abusive behaviour of their employees. Oxfam must feel consequences for its failures in selecting and monitoring employees. Cooperation with Osfam must therefore not continue in the same way; the Commission is also called upon to do so.  Development aid policy also needs a change of direction. We know that of every euro of donation and development aid, only a fraction of the really needy are received. A large number of actors – bureaucrats, NGOs and development workers, and also a kleptocratic political class found in many African countries – have squeezed between the source of money and the recipients. Unfortunately, the wrong people are making their pockets full with development aid. The solution does not come from more money, nor is it to the state funding of NGOs. The right way is a new and better trade policy. We must stop subsidising our agricultural sector and instead open it up more to products from developing countries. Far too few people in this House want to get involved – it is the only way. It is also the only way to eliminate the causes of flight, which are so often talked about here.

name: André ELISSEN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, today we are talking about the abuses of aid organisations such as Oxfam. In recent months, stories have surfaced of perverted sex parties in Haiti. Oxfam employees have been scandalously misbehaving there, including at the expense of the European taxpayer. Hundreds of millions of euros have been sent to Haiti since 2010. It is only since the beginning of this year that we have started to get a picture of how that money has been spent, and that image is not pretty, I can tell you.  Unfortunately, the scandal in Haiti does not appear to be isolated. For example, some Oxfam employees who misbehaved in Haiti appear to have engaged in the same practices in Chad a few years earlier. Scandalous and unacceptable.  Oxfam is certainly no exception, because scandals are also rife in other organisations. Take, for example, Greenpeace. Two days ago it was announced that no less than 44 former employees from South America have been kicked out of the school. There are alleged to have been several cases of unwanted behaviour and abuse in recent years. The complainants were dismissed, the perpetrators were held over their heads. Outrageous.  The list of examples of abuse is getting longer and longer. Pretty much every aid organization has to deal with it. Mr President, even then, the majority of this House is looking the other way and tough text is being put forward and so-called hefty measures are being announced. But when it comes down to it, everything stays the way it was.  Every year, more than €75 billion is spent from Europe on development aid and related issues. Of this, 10 billion will be given away by the European Parliament.  Mr President, it is time to stop blatantly transferring billions, transferring billions to corrupt, dictatorial regimes and so-called aid organisations. This is despite the fact that these expenditures are not or hardly controlled and therefore one has no idea of what the money is being spent on. This has to stop. Development aid and all kinds of related expenditure must once again become an exclusive competence of the Member States. Each country must be able to decide for itself whether, and if so, how much money should be transferred to the bottomless pit called development aid.  Mr President, as far as I and my party are concerned, it is clear: not a penny to corrupt dictatorial regimes and so-called aid organisations. People who have misbehaved must be dealt with harshly.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I am sorry about the decision. I think this is an extremely important topic and the police have expressed their outrage at some of the events that have been reported in recent times. It has been a very bad time for charities in general. I know that in my own country there were a number of scandals relating to financial misappropriation, where various charities, who had the confidence of the public, were collecting money and then it was seen not to be used for the proper purposes. They were giving themselves some very big wages, employing family members and were not 100% accountable. Then, as was pointed out here by members of the House and the Commissioner, the worst situation was where aid organisations which are very reputable and have a highly-valued reputation were seen to be doing the exact opposite to helping people and were exploiting them. I welcome the Commissioner’s guarantees that there be zero tolerance for this, and I think that is the key. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: blue card issue. – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent Mr Kelly, i would like to begin by I know that, compared to my country, Latvia, Ireland is much more progressive – I would say – in the fight against the sexual exploitation of women, especially when, under cover, under the guise, such cruel crimes are committed under charities. Perhaps you could share your experience of literally naming the best you could perhaps be proud of as an elected Member from your country.

name: Seán KELLY
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much, Mr Mamikins. Indeed, but, as I said, even in Ireland we had some scandals – mainly financial – and it really rocked genuine charities, because the funding for many of them, who would do wonderful work, went way down accordingly. I think the same will happen with the likes of Oxfam and many more unless we can actually prove and show people here in the European Parliament that we are on top of our game, that we know what is happening with the funding, and that, where there are any exploitative measures being been taken, that we have zero tolerance. I trust the Commission to do that.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I have taken the word above all to support my colleague Federley who has proposed this item on the agenda because he goes for nothing to hide. When scandals are what they are, like the Oxfam scandal, we really have nothing to hide.  And that's where I have to say right at the beginning that I also support the line that the Commission is taking. I think Commissioner Stylianides has made it very clear today what the Commission's ambitions are and which way they will go. Why? Because we just heard, a few minutes ago, colleagues on the far right who would like such adventurers, not to say bullies, to just abolish aid to those who need it most.  Let's not have those standards. We know very well that many people really need European help. Many who suffer. And those who do scandals like this should be pursued with utmost action and, of course, punished by all legal means.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you so much for your remarks and for you suggestions. I completely agree with you about zero tolerance and, of course – above all – prevention. The recent cases of sexual misconduct reminded us firstly, that we need to continue to work towards a zero-tolerance culture against sexual exploitation and abuse. There is absolutely no room for relaxed efforts and lenient behaviour towards allegations of any kind of misconduct. Secondly, we need to live up to our ethical and legal responsibilities as a leading donor of humanitarian and development assistance across the world. We need to support all our partners in their efforts to prevent, to identify at an early stage, and to respond to cases of sexual misconduct. We also need more transparency and more accountability across the board. We need to safeguard our work. Our role is unique; saving lives and empowering people is a fair and upright duty. So our work is too important to be compromised. This is my very strict message to all our partners. I shall now answer some specific issues, and I would like to start with Oxfam. We have collectively suspended the conclusion of any new contracts – these amount to a total of more than EUR 90 million – until we are satisfied with the new mechanisms put in place to prevent, report and respond to sexual abuse. With regard to our support to António Guterres’s efforts, as the European Union we fully apply the UN standards of behaviour in its Common Security and Defence Policy missions, and this year the Council adopted revised standards of behaviour. Of course, as António Guterres has said many times, again, no zero tolerance for sexual abuse allegations. And as regards our monitoring of the use of our funding: first, we assess the financial, operational and administrative capacities of the NGOs that apply to receive funding. Secondly, we carry out regular on-site visits during the implementation of the project on the ground. Third, audits of management and control systems are performed during the implementation of the action, and this includes visits to the project sites, implementing partners and beneficiaries. And fourth, there are audits of legality and regularity of the operations once the projects are finished. By way of example, in the humanitarian field (in my field), last year 50 projects with a value of almost EUR 500 million were audited during their implementation and no issues relating to sexual misconduct were detected during these audits. So no doubt we have to continue in order to fight against any sexual abuse, but there is also the other side of the coin, and this is why I mention our audits through 50 partners on the ground.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – European Socialists consider it essential to keep in mind that in any humanitarian emergency there is a serious risk of abuse and/or sexual exploitation of people in extreme vulnerability. We are therefore gravely concerned that the culture of silence, intimidation and abuse will continue as soon as the media focus is shifted from this problem. The European Union should reconsider funding from non-governmental organizations such as Oxfam after reports have been known that some of its employees paid for sex to disaster victims while on humanitarian missions. Mention aside deserves the United Nations, which has deafly heard allegations of abuse of Syrian women that for at least three years had been being carried out by some of its employees and organizations such as the International Rescue Committee. This problem needs to be made visible and the protection of women and girls ensured in order to prevent sexual exploitation in war situations or in the context of humanitarian disasters of any kind. It is not possible to continue to ignore systematic abuses or tolerate victims fearing precisely those organizations that are supposed to ensure their well-being and, finally, their survival.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the debate on the great inquiry with a written response request and debate by J rg Meuthen at the Commission: Celebrating international Family Day (15 May) (G-0000004/2018 - B8-0021/2018) (2018/2722 (RSP)).

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We are now talking about my great question on the occasion of International Family Day. The Commissioners responsible for this policy, Mr Jourova and Mr Timmermans, are absent from this debate. Mr Timmermans may be recovering from Christopher Street Day in Brussels. Instead, the Selmayr Commission sends the Civil Protection Commissioner to read out an official's response. The EU has silenced the United Nations International Family Day. All people of good will recognise that the EU does not value the family based on marriage between a man and a woman, but on the mysterious International Day against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia, the rainbow flag of gender ideologues fluttered at the EU buildings. Brussels is thus devalues the sovereign symbols of the Member States. Human resources departments made a huge effort for transgender Eurocrats in the workplace. These are the EU's priorities in the management of values and standards. What the EU is doing for marriage and the family is to simplify the divorce of binational couples, to demand the boundless diversity of marriage for all, even where no one wants women to explicitly limit the value added by women only to the formalised labour market and to allow children to be raised gender-neutrally and unidentity-free in day-care. When do you think the Selmayr Commission declares surrogacy to be a cross-border service? This European Union implements all the communist recipes that Karl Marx has recommended for the destruction of functioning families. By the way, you cannot hope for any resistance from Christian-democratic parties. This is demonstrated by the results of our roll-call vote. I see this as a major cause of the Union's self-inflicted self-dismay. I would therefore like to express my thanks to my Slovak colleague, Anna Zaborska, who, as chairwoman of the Family Intergroup, is working tirelessly to ensure that Europe does not one day abolish itself on the basis of wrong political priorities.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of my dear colleagues Věra Jourová and Marianne Thyssen, I am here to address this issue: the International Day of the Family. You know that it is a United Nations initiative. As UN members, EU Member States may observe this day. However, as it is not an EU initiative, as such, it does not receive any specific support from the Commission. Family policy is primarily a Member State competence. The Commission supports Member States’ efforts on family and child policies through political guidance, including in the context of the European Semester. EU financial support is also available. The EU rules can affect family law in cross-border cases affecting, for example, divorce and separation, marriage, civil partnership and property issues like succession and wills, and in this area of civil law the Commission has proposed, in the recent period, rules to better protect children in cross-border family proceedings. The European Pillar of Social Rights, adopted on 26 April 2017, is our reference framework to screen the performance of our labour markets and social protection systems with respect to challenges and people’s needs. It puts forward a new generation of rights, in particular access to social protection, thus promoting universality of support for all in need, starting with children and their families. The Pillar constitute the EU’s main implementation tool for translating the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals into a European context. Concretely, the Commission put forward an initiative to support work/life balance for parents and carers. This package seeks to modernise work/life balance policies across the EU and to deliver measures that will improve the daily lives of many families. We hope that the Council will reach a political agreement on the text shortly, opening the way for constructive negotiations with the European Parliament. The role of families is also crucial for the successful integration of migrants. For example, evidence suggests that immigrant children and natives with immigrant parents typically have worse education and labour market outcomes than their peers with native parents. Migrant parents’ level of education and employment status has a significant impact on their children’s outcome. Investing in integration measures for family migrants, especially for women, is key for the future well-being, prosperity and cohesion of our societies – European societies – and, of course, labour markets. The Commission also provides important financial support to various NGOs, including Eurocarers, Eurochild and COFACE Families Europe. The action undertaken by these NGOs substantially contributes to EU policy-making in the social area and increases awareness-raising on the issues related to the work of family members. I think it is quite important to have this discussion in Parliament, and thank you so much for your interpellation.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: for the PPE Group. – Madam President, this year's theme of UN International Family Day is families and inclusive societies. We in Slovakia chose the motto "We stand by each other" for family day. The common denominator of these two perspectives is the mutual solidarity that arises in the family and from there spills over into the wider community. In the European Union, too, we talk a lot about inclusion. True inclusion is based on the ability and willingness of people to stand not side by side, but with each other. Strong with the weak, healthy for the sick, the rich for the poor, those who live in surplus, those who are in short supply. "We stand by each other" is an expression of proximity that allows you to shake hands, support, comfort, simply help each other whenever necessary. This close proximity, this solidarity, we're learning in the family. As regards the direct influence of social policy, including social protection, the European Union has very limited powers. Its role, as defined in the Treaties, is to support and complement the activities of the Member States in this area. However, any political decision at European Union level has an indirect impact on the family. The rules governing the Single European Market, foreign and security policy, the rights and obligations of european Union citizens, even the prohibition of discrimination, all affect family life. Commissioner, colleagues, it is therefore so important that the Commission also incorporates in its reflections the impact of the legislation proposed by it on the family.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, although families all over the world have transformed greatly over the past decades, in terms of their structure and as a result of global trends and demographic changes, the United Nations still recognises the family as a basic unit of society, and the International Day of Families which is observed by the UN on 15 May every year is the best proof of that. I am convinced that, with time, everybody realises that the most important values, in life is family. No amount of money, clothes or even a good job can be compared with the family. Only relatives and loved ones, with a smile on their faces communicating with us, can bring us true joy and happiness. Only at home can we always show our true emotions and find moral support and practical advice. And the family is the main source of our inner soul power. In my opinion, every person’s success in life directly depends on the relations in his or her family. Unfortunately, there are problems which families face every day: for example, poverty, lack of social support, and an absence of equal rights among family members. In a special risk category are such vulnerable social groups as young families, migrants, ethnic minorities, and families with persons with disabilities. To resolve these issues, the European Union is developing an approach to family policies for inclusive societies. The main aim is to raise awareness of the role of families and family-oriented policies in achieving more inclusive societies. The primary emphasis is put on social inclusion and the protection of various types of families to facilitate their full inclusion in the mainstream of society. This can be achieved through implementing the following points: for example, firstly ensuring equal justice to all family members, especially women; secondly, providing universal birth registration and legal identity for all, especially targeting vulnerable families; and lastly, developing and promoting social protection. These are key points in order to save and support such things as cohesion, unity, empathy, integrity and solidarity.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The fact that the UN declared 15 May international family day is of course important, but not in the celebrations or the flags proposed – even beautifully designed – is a problem, but in creating the right conditions for the development and functioning of a family that plays a huge role in educating young generations, being an environment in which children learn fundamental values, love, respect or selfless help. Children without good role models have difficulties in developing, in coexisting, difficulties in respecting moral values.  The problems of modern families are caused not only by financial scarcity as a result of the huge social stratification with unemployment and low wages, but also by the increase in the cost of education, which is sometimes the reason for neglecting educational responsibilities. Besides, of course, anti-family ideologies leading to various pathologies. The disappearance of multigenerational families with isolation of the elderly is also a major problem.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Dear Chairman, I belong to liberals as the Chairman said and basically we start with the freedom and happiness of the individual. As liberals, we respect one of those personal principles, which is to love your neighbor whatever he may be. Whether he was gay, transsexual or anything else. Love thy neighbor. And that's why I'm saying this to a colleague who made this point, which starts with a traditional family. Women are finally equal. Let's figure it out once.  But on the other hand, I will say very clearly: I respect and support the celebration of international family day because I think it is very important, that it is inclusive and that it certainly contributes to solidarity. Contributes more love, contributes more happiness. But let's never forget those who may not have that luck. And I think and I want to think about them further.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, listening to some Members I am a little embarrassed, honestly: 'Dad, Mom, Dad, Dad, Mom, Mom...'. Without Dad, uncle, grandfather, even people living alone and still feel like families.  We must have a little respect in this Parliament for people, because there are many people we represent who vote for us, and who have the same right to have a family and to feel family regardless of their sexual orientation.  So, please, a respect. For these statements hurt us; they hurt us like people, they hurt us like politicians, and I have to say it that way.  Nuclear families, extensive, single-parent, adoptive, separated parents, host families, reconstituted... Families. Capitalized. Families.  And that is why the European Commission has decided not to celebrate this day, I think it is normal. Because the European Commission has many more problems to deal with and these are problems such as making a European Social Fund that can ensure that people, that families have the capacity to have social welfare, so that they can have a decent life; so that these families can have housing, decent schools.   It doesn't matter one day, it doesn't matter the celebration of a day. What matters is making serious policies so that families can have good conditions.  And, look, the family, Mr Member — the author of the major question - is more than just a biological concept: it is inclusion.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, International Family Day is an opportunity for us to realise the foundation on which our lives stand. Let me quote: "Family is a space in which a person's personality is formed. A space for the creation of human capital, the upbringing and growth of future generations. As such, it is undoubtedly the basic and most important unit of our company. Only stable and prosperous families guarantee a good environment for raising children, sustainable development and society, its functionality and cohesion. The role of families in society is irreplaceable". Colleagues, this is not an archaic text. This is the concept of family policy of the Government of the Czech Republic from 2017, i.e. the text very contemporary. I'm glad I was able to read it, because that's really the way it is, we just need a family. But I ask: How do we take care of her? The European Union does not have direct competence in family policy, but in fact every decision we make here affects the families in their lives. We should support parents, we should appreciate their care, and we should also support parenting education. Unfortunately, for example today, we have instead approved recommendations on social education, on guarantees for children. Instead of families, it is supposed to guarantee the social standard of the European Union. I am a great supporter of the European Union, but I fear that if we question the family, our common ground, then we are also breaking the foundation of the European Community. Madame la Présidente, la dernière fois, j'avais le plaisir d'annoncer que j'étais grand-mère pour la première fois. Aujourd'hui, is suis grand-mère pour la deuxième fois et j'ai ici ma petite-fille, qui s'appelle Stella. C'est aussi ma famille, c'est la fête des familles. Alors, merci beaucoup pour votre compréhension.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Welcome to Stella. We will follow the adventures of your family with each great inquiry, Mrs. Ojdrov. I wish you many grandchildren.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the idea of honouring the International Day of the Family goes back to 1993. I think it is a very good one, but of course we perhaps have a different interpretation of family now than we might have had a number of years ago.  Ms Miranda is right that, regardless of their composition, given different situations, all families are very important, and the more stable they are, the more stable society is. This year’s theme was ‘family and inclusive society’. I think that was a very good theme, because we do need to do more in terms of being more inclusive and welcoming in modern society. You start with the family, and that is very important. As well as that, it is often the family that is the place that you go to for real care and compassion in times of true struggle and, without a stable family, it can be very difficult to deal with issues like that. I also think that the social, economic and demographic issues are to be considered, and I know that in my own country the emphasis would have to be on mental health and homelessness. These issues are being dealt with in relation to the family and, indeed, individuals. Finally, I just want to say that last year’s theme was finding a work-life balance. In some respects I suppose that we politicians are the worst people to talk about that, because being away from home, as MEPs, and spending weekends doing our work, without a supporting family behind us – an understanding family – we just couldn’t continue. So we can be very grateful for all our families, no matter what their composition is. (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Seán KELLY
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, indeed we have had a tradition of large families in the past: I know that from my own background in Gaelic Athletic Association football and hurling. Some families almost made up the entire team: you would have four, five or six from the one family playing in the team. But the trend in modern life, as in all advancing economies, is that the families tend to be a smaller now. Thankfully, I have four children myself: two boys and two girls – a good balance. I am very happy with them, I hope they are happy with me, even though they don’t see me often enough.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I happen to have got into the debate, if you like. I could also get out - father, grandfather, several children. I would like to see such a debate on the family lead to better airtime. That would be the first point. Because there is a lot to discuss, and there are also disadvantages. I also admit that in democracy this is sometimes the case: you must always strike a balance between the majority and interest in minorities. Sometimes this does not work out properly. In Germany, too, we have problems which speak demonstrably of the disadvantage of families, that is right. So the task for the relevant committees to look at the problem once again is also a matter for the relevant committees. Secondly, what annoyed me a little: I had to go through a socialist educational path, and it is likely that classics can be interpreted differently – as the previous speaker, Mr Meuthen, did. So, it was always said in socialism: the family is the smallest unit of society, which must be nurtured and nurtured. There were already contradictions. My second request is that we should not abuse the concept of family ideologically and politically.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have been a member of the Family Party for ten years and have enjoyed it for ten years, in which I have been able to be there for the children as well. When we argue here, we should argue politically, not too emotionally. There is a great deal of argument and much to be argued about here in Parliament, which makes life difficult for parents. This is not justice. And if we strengthen other sides and thereby weaken parents, then that is anti-family policy. I hope that in future politics we will always ensure that there is intergenerational justice – that is family policy – that the educational benefits of parents, especially mothers, are recognised. It is not acceptable for mothers of more and more children to receive an ever-lower pension. There is something wrong with the system. We really need an education salary, adjusted for the money that others get for the same benefit in kindergarten, in the nativity scene and other professions that are basically equivalent to parental benefit, for example in the children's home. We do not just need spousal splitting, we need family splitting where the children are counted. We need a family suffrage – a right, a human being, a voice. And if we want to eliminate the risk of poverty in children, we must also ensure that parents are repeatedly called upon. They are also penalised in the tax. They have to pay many times as much in taxes, because they always pay for the children at the value added tax and thereby also fill the tax bag of the corresponding state. Solidarity is needed here. And so thank you very much. One minute is not enough. But I hope that in the future we will really always have the families on board with the political interests.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank colleagues for this really interesting discussion. It was a really interesting debate. I am sure that we will have new opportunities to discuss this really interesting issue of the International Day of the Family in more detail, but also, in a broader manner, the role of the family in our societies.
